Jan 11 2009 	Get Ready to tip everyone.....who works there	When you arrive get ready for tipping first the porter just for opening the the door for you he looks forward for a tip, then we went to check-inn which was fast but room wasn't ready but we where early, we didn't mind so we gave the luggage to the guy who controls the luggae room- , he asked for money, then again when we picked the luggage, and when we where leaving same routine, even to book a cab from concierge you have to pay a tip, Greedy staff............ The room wasn't that bad (half clean mind you) comftable bed, but when you enter the bathroom you will have a shock, it's a room with an old sink and a curtuian in the middle of the room. The good thing a bout this hotel it''s in a central area of manhattan, it's in a quite area and it's very safe and the lobby is very nice which looks like a 5 star hotel. Jan 9 2009 	Nothing special	Hello,We were in New York during the holidays and we stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel. It was definetly not the freshest hotel we stayed at. Jan 9 2009	Great President/Bad Hotel	Priceline sold this as a 31/2* hotel. It was not. The heat could not be controled in the room. It was either on (too hot) or off(too cold). So I attempted to open the window at which point I pulled a muscle and walked around NY for 4 days in pain. The window did open. This did control the heat. Oh and the heater was noisey.In order to get the toilet to flush you had to hold the handle down for 10 seconds.The room doors are heavy and the doors slam if yiou are not careful and most guests are not. So if you are a light sleeper,stay away..They charge $15 a day for internet. Other hotels are free.The rooms are decorated in very old styles and there is nothing attractive about them. I had one small trash can and had to ask for another.I had to ask to have the smelly shower curtain changed and there was a left over mouth wash bottle given to me. The sink, hidden by the shower curtain, juts out into the tub and while trying to adjust the drain I cracked my head on the sink. I thought this was my demise. I just have a large bump.I'm happy I got out alive.Oh and when I wanted a cab one day I asked the door man if this is where I should stand for a taxi. He said yes, but just stood there too. I saked if he assisted guests? He said"Well lady you didn't ask that." What a control freak. I got my own taxi and he lost a tip.The loby was nice and the front desk staff was curteous.The concierge sent us to a closed restaurant.

Jan 7 2009 	Great Location	Our dealings through the hotels website and over the phone was really good, the staff we dealt with on the phone were polite and helpful, so I was sort of expecting the same when we arrived. We didn't arrive at the hotel until 11pm, it was lashing down with rain and there was no bellman, a guy who was staying at the hotel helped us in with our luggage, and were we glad he did as there was a flight of stairs to climb to the lobby. There were bellmen at their desk and they watched this guy carry our bags up the stairs, offered no help and were very dismissive when he informed them that there was no bellman outside to help us. The reception staff were also dismissive, after I gave my name to check in a registration form was plonked in front of me to sign, we were handed our room key and told "you're on the 16th floor".......in a very bored voice.The room was very shabby and we actually thought they had given us the wrong room. We booked a superior room with 2 double beds, and it certainly didn't match up to the photos or description on their site. We asked at the front desk (a different person than before) to check we were in the right room and was told in the same indifferent, bored voice that "yes, it's a superior" we stated we weren't very happy, there was wallpaper peeling off, the enamel was peeling off the bath, and were told "there's no other rooms available" and then turned away from us. So great service is NOT one of their strong points, especially the reception staff. The bellmen got better while we were there and we ended up quite liking them, they were very helpful.The room was very small and very shabby, as I described earlier, in fact it was so small that you couldn't pull the chair out from under the desk as it hit the foot of the bed. The lobby is fantastic, and when you've seen that and the photos of the hotel rooms on the website it was a real letdown to walk into our room. Although we were there in the middle of December, the room was boiling. Even with the window open and the air con on full blast it was still roasting. Food is very expensive and I wouldn't recommend room service, costs a fortune and it wasn't very good either, but there are so many places nearby to eat that doesn't really matter. Another huge annoyance was no coffee/tea making facilities in the room or mini bar for a cold drink.BUT the huge plus that would make me stay there again (now I know what to expect) is the location. It was perfect - right around the corner from 5th ave, a few blocks from Empire State, right around the corner from Grand Central, a few blocks from Times Square.......we walked EVERYWHERE........the location is what really sells this hotel, so if all you want is a bed for the night with no frills and want to be right in the heart of everything then I would definately use this hotel.

Jan 4 2009 	Run-Down	I have stayed in New York often and know it is difficult to find good hotels there for less than $200. We paid about 140 for this via Priceline. For that price, I've stayed at nicer places in the city - difficult to do but possible and worth looking.I would urge everyone to stay clear of this hotel. The rooms are suitable if you have low standards and don't mind ratty furniture and carpets. Any couple looking for a nice or romantic place should be especially weary since there is nothing even remotely romantic about the rooms - we felt like we were staying in the shining. When looking at the pics of the website, be aware the rooms look much better than they actually are - take those room pics and subtract 20 years of wear and tear. Not worth the even bargain price we paid.Btw, rude staff and poor service dont matter to me, but clean rooms do. As for the staff, they were nice enough although the lobby was very crowded. The whole hotel felt run down and musty.Also, this is my first review ever but the experience was bad enough to urge me to write this review. Would hate to see other people waste their money on this place..

Jan 4 2009 	Great Location and Price Needs a Facelift	The location of this hotel is awesome and the package I got with our airfare made it very affordable. However, I will caution that it badly needs a facelift, sort of what you would have expected in the mid-eighties. We had booked a non-smoking room and it wasn't available. When we got off the elevator, the entire hallway had a haze to it. Surprisingly, our room wasn't too bad for smell and we had been given a corner room which was about three times as large as a normal NYC room. My other caution is with regard to the bell desk. I had made arrangements to get a set fare car to the airport and was told it wouldn't be a problem, to return in an hour and it would be waiting. When we returned, I was told by a different staff member that there were no set fare cars available but that he had a cab ready to take me. I protested and suddenly the town car sitting right in front of the building was mine, as previously arranged. I had earlier seen money surreptitiously changing hands between the cabbies and the bellmen. Now I understand why. We didn't spend much time in our room, so this met our needs. If you plan on seeing a lot and are not concerned about hotel amenities, this is a good location and price for a home base.

Jan 3 2009 	Good All Rounder	Had read mixed reviews about this hotel but I personally found it fine. It is what it claims to be. A well located hotel with old world charm. Old world charm doesn't come with shiny new appliances as a result the furniture may be a bit battered but everything was clean, rooms were well equipped and service was professional. The hotel has character and a personality. The lobby and liunge area have the wow factor on arrival and it's nice to sit around and soak up the atmosphere. Put on a dress, sip a cocktail () sorted!

Dec 31 2008 	Great location!	This hotel is located right by Grand Central Station so it makes it very convenient and so accessible. It's also walking distance to a bunch of other places such as Rockefeller Center, United Nations, Times Square, some of the best shopping places, and even Central Park if you have your walking shoes on! The rooms are a bit small, but for the value, its not so bad, considering its in Midtown. The staff was very nice and accommodating. They also let us borrow a couple hotel umbrellas as it was raining during our stay and arranged for a town car to pick us up and take us to the airport after checking out. It was a great, I will definitely stay here again.

Dec 27 2008	No No No ...	I am travelling a lot and seen a lot of countries and hotels, but this one was the worst hotel I have ever been in.There is NOTHING good in this hotel, it's just in the good location. Dec 26 2008	Jaded. Give it a pass.	Prior to arriving we were excited about staying in a real New York hotel, like we had seen in the movies. On arriving, several bellhops stood around watching while my wife and I hauled our heavy suitcases up the large set of stairs into the lobby. Only once we finally got to the top did any one of them come forward offering to help. Throughout our stay the staff always seemed to expect a tip, which I expected, but not for doing almost nothing for us. The front desk staff seemed jaded and indifferent. The rooms were small, as we had expected, but also not in good shape. The bathroom shower system was terrible, leaving pools of water all over the floor. There was no coffee maker or any extras in the room whatsoever. And it seemed like it could use a good thorough cleaning, or at least a good renovation. The concierge was helpful in helping us to plan our activities, although again he seems jaded and really didn't offer anything more than the bare limits of his job description. The brunch was tasty, but expensive so it had better be. Overall, this hotel was not a good experience for our first time to New York. I would definitely not go back. We popped in to some other hotels while wandering around New York, and most times we were warmly greeted, unlike the Rosevelt.

Dec 18 2008 	Fantastic Hotel Ignore the Other Reviews!	Hotel was booked through Travel Zoo where it was a featured offer - superior room with breakfast. My husband and I went to New York for my 'much dreaded' birthday and we mentioned this at check-in. We were delighted to find out we had been upgraded to a suite which I later found out cost $1700 per night! The suite was spotlessly clean and enormous - we had a lounge with a sofa and two armchairs, coffee tables and two 42" wide screen televisions! There was a kitchen area and a dining room area for 4 people to eat! The breakfast was great and well worth having because you didn't need to eat for the rest of the day. Huge choices of cooked food plus omelettes (the omelette cook was pretty miserable but her omelettes were great) and waffles to order. Loads of fresh fruit and freshly cooked bread and pastries. The location is great, 5 mins from Grand Central Station and you could walk to 5th Avenue, the Rockerfeller Centre and most other places. We bought a one day bus pass (the downtown route is the best) and if your time is limited this is the best thing you can do. You simply get on and off as you want. The price for the ticket from the hotel concierge is the same price as at the bus stop and of course you can pay by credit card which you might prefer. I am sorry that other people didn't have such a great time as us, but I really can't fault this hotel in anyway. Special thanks to Paulette for the upgrade.

Dec 17 2008	Best value for your money in NYC!	My mom and I recently took a quick 2-day trip to NYC to enjoy the Christmas decorations. We stayed at the Roosevelt b/c we stayed there back in 1995 and it was ok. It has since been renovated and it is really nice. It's very clean, safe, comfortable, and convenient. The price was great too - less than $150/night which seems to be a deal based on my research for this time of year in Manhattan. The only negative thing I noticed was the room was a bit noisy. But who goes to NYC to sit in a hotel room?? I would definitely stay at the Roosevelt again. Highly recommended.

Dec 17 2008 	Not recommended	My company booked us a business stay at The Roosevelt earlier this month. I would not recommend it. Dec 12 2008 	Not fabulous not terrible.	Just stayed here 2 nights on a business trip and have to agree with previous 2 posts. The lobby is very impressive (especially when all decked out in its holiday finery) and the location is really great, both for proximity to tourist sites (Rockefeller Center, Times Square) & the city's commercial center (for my business appointments, at least). The rooms are perfectly serviceable, but not extraordinary. Overall I feel like the place could've done with a good dusting and carpet cleaning. As for room size, I booked a "cozy queen" room (and we all know that "cozy" is just a euphemism for minuscule), so I was expecting the room to be the size of a broom closet, but was pleasantly surprised to find that it was a decent size.I also stayed here years ago, since which time the hotel has been renovated, and it's definitely much better than it used to be. I would most likely stay here again.

Dec 11 2008 	just ok	..great location for shopping,, not a child friendly hotel but great for couples and business people...lobby is stunning, rooms very basic, holes in bed linen, dust behind and under bed inch thick, curtains look as though they have never been washed, no tea and coffee facilities...staff keep themselves to themselves but polite when approached...if you love shopping and got lots of money to spend then this is an amazing place, however due to the recent economic problems bargins were very few and far between.

Dec 9 2008 	Fantastic Location - Not so sure about the staff	My boyfriend and I were staying in New York for sight seeing and Christmas shopping. The Roosevelt had a great location and we were really pleased when we checked in. Then as we were leaving we were verbally abused at the front of the hotel by the concierge for only having a one dollar bill. I know americans expect tips, and we have no problem giving a tip when we have had good service - but this guy had just hailed us a cab! That was his job! We were really disappointed by the attitude of the staff.Our room was nice, the bed was very 'squishy' (almost too soft for me) and the air con rattled like nothing i'd ever heard! Dec 8 2008 	Fantastic Location	I stayed at the Roosevelt for 4 nights and had a great time. Dec 8 2008	Loved the location	We got a good rate (saw it on travelzoo) for a busy time of year. The location was great for us, near transportation and nidtown attractions. Dec 1 2008 	Giving thanks for the Roosevelt	I spent Thanksgiving, as I do each year, in New York City.I try a different hotel each time and this trip it was the Roosevelt.The Roosevelt is a "grand old hotel" in a fabulous location on 45th & Madison.I booked a deluxe room and I am glad that I did, as peeking into "superior" rooms, I saw that they are quite small.I called Alan in guest services well in advance of my trip to ask for a spacious, bright, quiet room with a bathtub. He said he'd take care of it and he did!My room was just what I needed, on a corner with plenty of light, and on the top floor (18).The bed was quite comfy and the room well appointed. Flat screen TV and safe, but no in-room coffee maker or robes.The age of the crown moulding was showing and the bathroom small, but over all, this was a very pleasant room.I did meet Alan when he came to make sure that I was taken care of and I showed my appreciation for his attention monitarily. He continued to be at my disposal throughout my stay, even sending up a refrigerator at no charge.The water pressure was weak, to say the least, and it took quite some time to fill the bathtub, although the shower was fine. There is no view to speak of at the hotel.The lobby bar was a nice place to have a drink and watch people move through the holiday-decorated lobby. The food was quite good, especially the enormous crab cake. Prepare for New York prices though.The staff, especially the maids, were extremely pleasant and helpful.All-in-all, I would recommend the Roosevelt. You can't beat the location (2 blks from Grand Central) and the value for what you get.Way to go Alan!Thanks for a great Thanksgiving!

Nov 30 2008	Great Hotel even better location	The Roosevelt Hotel, wow really good hotel, well mannerd staff and helpful, looks great espeically in the reception and bar. The room wasnt quite as amazing as we had thought when booking as room only contained king size bed, chest of drawers, desk and desk chair with bedside cabinats and of course en suite, and it was quite small but too be honest your in New York and the hotel location on 5th avenue makes it an awesome hotel great for sightseeing and getting around everythings so close - can walk too Times Square, Rockafeller, Emprie State, Central Park.We stayed 7 nights and it was great I wouldnt recommed breakfast esp not if your on holiday as its so much easier too have bagels etc the choice is endless we had breakfast once it was average.Overall 10/10

Nov 24 2008	Great hotel for the price	Just got back from a long weekend stay at the Roosevelt. Met some girlfriends there so we had two rooms. One was a nicer corner room with a king. The other a smaller room with two queens. It was definitely on the smaller side (normal for NY, I understand) but it was not a problem for both of us to get ready at once. PROS: great location! Walking distance to Times Square, Theatre district, Grand Central Station. Hardly ever a wait for a taxi. Charming lobby. Comfortable rooms CONS: The room, especially the bathroom, was always sooo warm. It was freezing outside and the room was too warm! I also had a problem with the shower going between hot and cold. (I never had time to complain because we were so busy). Summary: I would say that it was a good bang for the buck. We got a really good deal through Travelzoo.com.

Nov 23 2008	Wonderful	Check-in was fast and friendly....got an upgrade when I mentioned this was my "retirement trip". Helpful, prompt staff. Room was great, with extras, also. Iron and ironing board, fantastic bed. I WILL stay there again. An exceptional location.

Nov 23 2008 	FANTASTIC - WILL BE BACK	This hotel is fantastic - the staff so helpful and courteous. We arrived and were were very warmly welcomed by a lovely receptionist, who informed us that we had been upgraded to a suite which was fab. Please ignore any negative reviews you may have read regarding this hotel. It really is really is great.

Nov 22 2008	Enjoyable stay at the ROOSEVELT	Just returned from New york, stayed for 5 days at the Roosevelt Hotel on 45th street, after reading very contrasting reports i was a bit unsure about staying there but please be reassured, my daughter and i arrived on the Saturday evening, checked straight in and shown to rooms within minutes( room 1214) it was a twin room with two queen size beds, lovely and clean with everything you should require while staying in the big apple, the hotel is a good example of a traditional hotel, it is not ultra chic, or modern but it does the job, everythin worked and the staff were all very friendly and helpful, the lobby is beautiful with a super xmas tree in the centre, bar prices expensive but everwhere was expensive,Location was excellent only a short walk from to TImes Square, Grand Central Station and the Empire state building, and for cheap breakfast you cant beat THE BROOKLYN BAGEL BAR opposite the empire state building bit scruffy looking but gorgeous coffee only 1 dollar and bagels to die for, a very enjoyable stay

Nov 22 2008 	Majestic dream came true	The first time I visited New York. Me and my wife are enchanted. Roosevelt is really above average and the location is the best. Nearby 5th and Times Square. You can walk to Empire State, Rockefeller Center, Broadway. Good Service and nice people.

Nov 21 2008 	Above Average	The Bar is extremely over priced ($10 for a small/bad glass of wine) and smells of wet dog, but the rest of the lobby was grand enough. The location is what sells this hotel, walking distance to most of the top attractions and right next to Grand Central Station for the rest of them.

Nov 16 2008 	Lovely old hotel friendly staff	My husband, two young daughters, and I stayed at the Roosevelt this past weekend. Everyone was very friendly and granted requests cheerfully, and our room was large and clean. We really enjoyed staying at the Roosevelt, and again, the staff were really so pleasant that they made our whole stay even more enjoyable than it already was.

Nov 16 2008 	Worst Hotel In New York A	I DONT OFTEN GIVE OUT BUT I Stayed at this hotel from Monday 10th - Saturday 15th October this is my 3rd time in new york 1st at the roosevelt and last. When we went to check in we were told to come back in 1 1/2 hrs to be told to come back in another 1hr ,On the 3rs afternoon the lock broke on our room door 1045 had to move room 1049 . The safe in the new room did not work and our toilet kept blocking. we got no help from main desk not there probem need to see the manager on duty who was always on the phone at the end we just stayed away from the hotel as much as possibe.There is a good irish bar between 2nd & 3rd on 47th . Nov 15 2008 	Great Location.	We recently stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel. The hotel is right across the street from Grand Central Terminal. We walked there for breakfast and dinner. There is a Rite Aid located there where we purchased snacks and bottled water. The hotel is a short walk from Times Square, Rockefeller Center and the Empire State Building. We were able to walk to most of the attractions and only had to use the subway one day of our stay.Our room was clean and the beds were comfortable. There were a few stains on the carpet in the hallway and a few small tears in the carpet in our room, but it didn't affect the quality of our stay. The shower head was loose, but the water ran just fine and we had plenty of hot water. We are a family of four and our room rate included breakfast for two. We were given breakfast vouchers when we checked in. My husband and I ate breakfast in the hotel and then took our two boys to a local Dunkin Donuts. One morning we decided to skip breakfast at the hotel and save the vouchers. We we planning to use four breakfast vouchers our last day at the hotel. We were later advised that we could use no more than two vouchers/day. We ended up going to Grand Central for breakfast and threw away the last four vouchers. I think the hotel could have allowed our family of four to use the remaining vouchers on the same day. We were entitled to free breakfast, but lost out because of the hotel policy of only two vouchers/day. Overall we had a very good stay and I would definitely stay there again. The location cannot be beat.

Nov 13 2008	Consistently good and friendly	I have found the reviews here to be helpful, so I am just returning the favor.I recently moved to upstate New York and travel to NYC fairly frequently for short stays.I have stayed at the Roosevelt several times. I have stayed with my 2 daughters as older teens /twenties , with my husband, as well as solo. Despite a few problems (which were quickly and cheerfully corrected) I gotta say I really like this hotel. It has a nice "feel".The lobby is wonderful in the "grand old" sense, the location is perfect if you are using Grand Central station for comings and goings, it is safe and friendly even for a woman traveling solo, the bar is welcoming and the bartenders know their stuff. The food is quite good at the hotel, but also good and much cheaper in the little diners, etc. throughout the city. Be aware that prices for drinks are high, as they are everywhere in New York (not just the City). Paying $10 - $12 for a cocktail or glass of wine is no biggie. I generally pay $150 - $225 US to stay here, and if I can't get a room at that price, I look elsewhere. At $150 / night a room here is a steal, even if it is of the not-as-lovely variety . At $225 / night it is still a good deal. I doubt I would pay over $275 NOT because the rooms and hotel aren't worth it, but because I know the city and where to find a better deal.Be aware that, as is the case with many hotels that have some "history", rooms may vary significantly in size, configuration, view, and decor, and the price does not always reflect this difference. I have stayed in a lovely, bright, large corner room with a huge bathroom and have also been assigned a less lovely, somewhat dark room...and paid essentially the same price. have had occasional problems with the rooms- once I was assigned a room with a poorly functioning air conditioner and another time the room was unacceptable due to conditions others have cited, however, I am impressed by the response of the staff in quickly, and without argument, assigning me a different room.In my experience, check-in , check out is always smooth, altho I rarely check in or out at peak times. The hotel will gladly store your bags if you get in early or have to wait after check out for a train, plane, or whatever.

Nov 13 2008 	Small mold blocked Fox News	Very small rooms. Closet was not even wide enough to hang my suits! Mold on walls around soap dish in extremely small shower. Not room to walk around bed with carry on bag on the floor. TV index shows FoxNews but upon entering that channel could not get. Called front desk and they said that channel was blocked and after asking why and was hung up on.I will not stay here again. However great location, but there are many other hotels in area.

Nov 11 2008 	Great Location - Disappointing Hotel	The location of this hotel is great - right near Grand Central Station, near the UN, some nice restaurants, etc. The lobby is lovely, but the rooms leave much to be desired. While I expect small in NYC, I don't expect dirty. Terrible to feel that you need a shower after you've taken a shower. We couldn't pull the curtains without using shoes to hold them back because the curtains hung over the air vents which blew all of the dirt and dust from the curtains throughout the room. The vents in the air conditioning/heating unit needed serious cleaning. While I usually don't use in-room movies - no issue here since they didn't provide any. The cable was also limited and no in-room coffee makers. The concierge was a bit behind the times - when I asked if he could check us in on our airlines via the internet p he didn't have a clue - finally we were able to find the business center and for a fee were able to check-in from there. The positives: the beds were comfortable - and there are now comforters that seemed clean, but the dust ruffles could have used some cleaning; and, the hotel did provide umbrellas and luggage storage. For such a grand old hotel it was rather disappointing that they have not been able to keep the rooms up to the same standard as the lobby.

Nov 6 2008	Great place to stay and location.	We stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel this past week and we were very pleased, the staff was really friendly. We were able to check in at 1:00 PM; our room had a crapy view on the third floor between the two towers and we could only see outside our window a flooding terrace, but we can live with that. The beds are really comfy and the pillows too. Everything was working and clean in the bed and the bathroom. Spacious closet. I think the price of the food is a little high but when you it is late, you can't walk anymore and are extremely tired, this is a good option. Food is good and service is great at the Restaurant, they go the extra mile for you.Right across the street there is an entrance to a passage to Grand Central Station and the little cafeteria Cos is a good place to get a good breakfast.I would stay again there.

Nov 4 2008 	Okay but a few hiccups	My husband and I stayed at the Roosevelt last Christmas, and it was a great experience. That is why I was disappointed with our stay there this weekend. We arrived at 2:45, after at seven hour drive, only to be told that we could not check-in until 3:30, despite the fact that check-in is at 3:00. The man at the front desk was completely unaccommodating and bordered on rude. He started our trip off on the wrong foot, and it was really frustrating.At 3:30 we were able to check-in to room 819. I was disappointed with the room, as it was slightly smaller and rather run down compared to the room we received last year. It really wasn't bad though. It was quite clean, and fairly comfortable.The Roosevelt is the warmest hotel I have ever stayed in! The temperature at night made it difficult for me to sleep. I had the same problem the first time I stayed there, and I am normally a very cold person. We had our AC cranked the entire time we were there and it was still hot!The hotel is very close to Times Square, Grand Central Terminal and shopping, but the area lacks character. It's an easy subway ride to more unique neighbourhoods though.Anyway I guess our stay was fine, but there were a few hiccups.

Nov 2 2008	Terrible experience!	As most reviews were quite positive about this hotel, we decided to stay here on our anniversary!What a mistake!!!Right from the beginning we were having problems. The person who checked us in was VERY arrogant and rude!As he wouldn't give us a nice deluxe room even though it was our anniversary and we came all the way from London, UK we asked for a room with a nice view.Well, our great view(as he described it!) was right in the corner overlooking another guest room!The room itself was very tiny. The bathroom was not better either, the paint was peeling off and the bathtub wasn't cleaned properly. We went back to reception to ask for a room with better standards and were told they are all the same! Shock of a lifetime and they were charging us $400 a night! Eventually we were moved to another room,same standard but at least cleaner.Our door had a huge gap at the bottom so you could clearly hear everything that was going on in the corridors.By this time we kind of accepted the fact that we were conned by the hotel but because it was nearly midnight and we were tired there was not much we could do.AS we were getting ready for bed we realized how cold it was so we called for an engineer to look at the heating system.He arrived within 5 minutes but as he was trying to fix the heater it blew!This meant we had to move room again in the middle of the night with 2 big suitcases and no help at all!At this point I was ready to start world war 3 at reception for all that they put us through.They clearly didn't want to argue so they upgraded us to a suite!Now that was probably worth the $400 as we got 2 bathrooms,a huge bedroom and an even bigger sitting room and dining room!I would not recomment this hotel to anyone!It's a rip off,the rooms are very dated and the staff have serious attitude problems.

Oct 31 2008 	Rude staff forced to have a smoking room	The location and the lobby/bar area is great. Aside from that, this place is a dump. Two girls at the front desk were so rude to us. We were told that our reservation doesn't guarantee a particular room (??). They couldn't find our reservation in the computer. I made the arrangements online, but they acted like it wasn't legitimate- it was their website!! They don't care if you complain- apparently they don't need or want your business!! They had already charged my credit card and it was late at night, or I would have left. But I'll take my $350/nt somewhere else next time.

Oct 31 2008 	Well located hotel	We stayed in this hotel as part of a package touring America. This hotel is very well located being a short walk from 5th Avenue and Time Square. We also found it possible to walk to all the other major sites including Empire state, Central park and the ferry to the statue of liberty although I would say that this was around three miles. The hotel is a traditional New York hotel and is fairly old fashioned. As we were staying four nights and we had asked for a double room the receptionist upgraded us although this didn't seem particularly special we did get a sneak look into some of the other rooms and were then quite happy with what we had been given. Rooms are small and fairly basic but are generally clean and surprisingly quiet considering you are in the middle of New York. It is hard to give an opinion on this hotel as I believe it is a victim of its traditional decor and design which does at least provide a good atmosphere of old style New York but also can look shabby. I probably would recommend this hotel but with a little reservation.

Oct 28 2008 	Nice hotel	After trawling through the Manhattan hotel reviews, we picked this one as it seemed to have more positive reviews than others. It is in a good location and easy to get hold of taxis, buses and subways.When we arrived about midday our room wasn't ready, we were told we were 24th in line for a room. There was no problem leaving our cases with the porter while we went out to explore, and our room was ready when we got back; they had told us to come back in a couple of hours and we did. There was no problem, either, looking after our cases when we checked out too because we didn't leave New York until much later in the day.We booked a CozyQueen, but when I told them it was our anniversary (true!) they upgraded us to a room with a king-size bed on the 6th floor. It was a nice good size room with an unspectacular view from the window.The weather was hot (low 70's in October!) and the air-conditioning was noisey. The choice was to have it on and be kept awake or turn it off and be baking hot. You could switch it on Low or High but both settings were noisey.The room was a good size and so was the bathroom. A small complaint about the bathroom was that the basin had a large crack in it, which didn't make it very hygenic. Also there was mold growing on the grouting of a few of the tiles around the bath, and the bath itself seemed to be pockmarked. Nothing very much to complain about, but the room wasn't cheap and I would expect better.We had good water pressure, but I overheard another guest in the lift say that on their floor higher up there was practically no pressure. The hotel did announce they were turning off the hot water for some maintenance during the day so that could have been part of the reason.The hotel has a Business Centre where you can use the Internet, but at a price. It was USD10.00 for 30 minutes or you could use it with a credit card where the minimum charge was USD3.00.Overall, a nice hotel where I would be happy to stay again.

Oct 24 2008 	World class	In short, this hotel is a dream come true. From the 16th to the 23rd of December last year my partner and I stayed at the Roosevelt Hotel NYC. Entering the hotel is like entering the set of a romantic movie. As you walk up the staircase into the lobby you are greeted by a beautifully decorated Christmas tree and a host of friendly staff and guests. The whole atmosphere sent butterflies to my stomach. I had looked forward to this trip so much, I was afraid encase I had set my expectations too high and was almost anticipating an anticlimax, but to my delight it was everything I had hoped it would be and more.After an extremely quick check in, (I mean literally 1 min), we made our way to the lift to take us to our new home for the week. Again there was a lovely surprise for us as we waited for the lift, some complimentary egg nog to further intensive the Christmas spirit.As we ascended to our room I could not have felt happier or more excited about the forthcoming week. This was most definitely not going to be any ordinary trip. I can honestly say Ive never been so far away from home and yet, felt so at home, (if that makes sense).We had booked to stay in the petite room and it was exactly that, however it was more than comfortable and the way in which the cleaning staff made up the rooms each day is to be highly commended. Every single day without fail, we were equipped with new towels and toiletries and the beds were always made to perfection, and that was in addition to the friendliness and politeness of the staff.In this review I must also mention the time and effort that the staff at the front desk put in to making our stay as enjoyable and fun packed as possible. We never felt lost. There was always a smiley face wanting to help, from Broadway tickets to the most time efficient ways of sight seeing, because lets be honest, its NY and there is almost too much to do. By the end of the week we were almost experts of where to go and what to see.MOST IMPORTANT!!!!!!!!!!!DO NOT TAKE THE BLUE SHUTTLE BUS!!!!!!!!!!!!We booked out tickets in advance and the service they provided was adequate from the airport to the hotel; however the more important trip, getting us to the airport in time for our flight home was disastrous!!!!!!! The disastrous part being that they didnt turn up. We booked our bus an hour earlier than we needed to just encase anything should happen and Im so glad we did. Our panic was short lived however, as you guessed it, lol, the Roosevelt staff came to the rescue and offered us the hotel car to take us to the airport. It was actually the door staff who sorted this problem for us. Although I dont know the mans name he really was a gentleman and did everything in his power to help us. He is a credit to that hotel. We did have to pay for the car but it was only $70 to Newark and when the average taxi is $50 and it meant we didnt miss our flight I thought this was more than reasonable. The car was most comfortable and it was the perfect end to a most memorable and romantic holiday. Few Additional PointsDef do Woodbury CommonsDef do Madame TaussaudsDef do a couple of Broadway showsDef do The Statue of LibertyDef do Ellis IslandDef do The Empire State BuildingDef SHOPAnd appreciate your time there because it will fly in, unfortunately.AND DEF DONT TAKE THE BLUE SHUTTLE BUS!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oct 23 2008	very good hotel. big rooms. great service	location is great (45th and madison). 5 min from times sq.big room, nice bath.the hotel is renovated and is "Old style", but very shiqu and clasic.the doormans were very helpful and volontiered themselvs to help.dont take their car to the airport. my driver tried to rip me off after the doorman said i'd have to pay a certien price (55$) he tried to take some more.overall - very good place.

Oct 19 2008 	Great stay!!!!!	We stayed at the Roosevelt over the weekend and it was great. At first I was hesitate to stay due to the recent dissatisfied reviews that were placed. Armondo at the front desk was terrific and a great help. We had drinks in the lobby and the martini's were excellent. Our room was clean and very roomy for NYC. The mattresses are new pillow top mattresses that are super comfy. We were on the 18th floor and had a view of the chrysler building which was nice. When we checked out on Sunday they held our bags and gifts that we bought in a secure room until we regretablely left for the day. From beginning to end we had a great stay at the Roosevelt and would not hesitate to book again. If your looking for a beautiful, clean hotel with a great location choose the Roosevelt you won't be disappointed.

Sep 29 2008 	Not all rooms are alike	My husband and I spent 3 nights in this hotel (9/25 through 9/28.) Sep 25 2008 	Great experience at the Roosevelt	My wife and I stayed for a long weekend (Sep 12-14) at the Roosevelt on a trip to see the city for the first time. I chose this hotel because of the positive things I had heard about it as well as it's great location in the city. Neither let us down! Located at the corner of 45th and Madison, the hotel is so close to Times Square, just a couple blocks from Grand Central Station and only about 10 blocks or so from Central Park. We walked nearly every where we went and this location was perfect for it. As for our room, it was fantastic. We ended up getting an upgrade to a suite which had so much room for New York City we didn't know what to do with ourselves. The concierge was very helpful, the valet parking was convenient and the check-in, check-out service at the front desk was very smooth. All in all, if you want to truly get the New York City feel by walking out of your hotel to the heart of the city and you want to do it at a reasonable rate, I can't recommend this hotel enough to you. If a low rate is more important to you, I would suggest just staying outside the city as the public transportation system works very well and would allow for little trouble if you're looking to save money on your stay.

Sep 17 2008 	Perfectly WONDERFUL	The Roosevelt is a great hotel. I recently stayed for a long weekend and had a wonderful experience. Sep 15 2008 	No problems despite concerns	We stayed at the Roosevelt for 6 nights from 30 August 2008.I had read hotel reviews of New York hotels til they were driving me mad - basically everywhere has both good and bad reviews. In the end I decided you can't be influenced too much by someone's bad experience, so I decided to book the Roosevelt despite having some concerns about the reviews about theft from the rooms. The reasons for choosing it were general central location, proximity to Grand Central Station, right sort of price range and size, and availability on the nights I wanted.Basically we had a great week there with no problems at all. We arrived too early for check in (1pm) but they did check us in no problem. The room was absolutely fine - two nice big comfortable beds. Air conditioning and safe worked fine, so did toilet and the shower was brilliant. Maybe not much space to hang stuff up or spread out cases but that is minor quibble.I'm pleased to say suffered no thefts or other problems. It was quiet, room cleaning fine, very little contact with other guests or staff so very much a 'hands off' feeling to it, especially when we took to getting the elevator from the lower Arcade level. Elevators were busy but no particularly long waits. The shop was useful for drinks for the night and was open late, also you could get ice from a machine to keep your drinks cool in.We never tried the breakfast in the end but had one evening meal in the restaurant behind the lobby - food was perfectly okay, I had a 'New York Strip' steak and New York cheesecake.Overall I would say our stay was a great success and I enjoyed it, and would definitely recommend it, however seeing other people's gripes about bad service etc I think the conclusion is that there's an element of luck involved in whether you have a good experience or not. I think I would advise not to get too hung up about reviews and don't get too stressed about everything having to be perfect.Oh, and I didn't see a single cockroach anywhere in New York!

Sep 12 2008	Loved the roosevelt	To book my reservation i contaated the hotel directly..i stayed for two nights on sept 4 to the 6 for 250 per night..everything was perfect, the room was perfect, the bathrrom was perfect also. i could not ask for more.. i was very socked..i would definitely stay here again and recommend thiks hotel to anyone. also the roomservice was great..a little pricey but worth it..during the process of check out if you need a taxi they will make sure they provide it for you. i had a cozy queen.. it was a corner room so i believe that made it a little more spacious im not sure but the room was a rather large.i was shocked considering all the reviews that ive read said that the rooms were small idk..i got to go ino the room beside me and it was huuuuge..it was also a corner room.. this hotel is in the center of anything. great locaiton and easy access to subway..walking distance to times square..just great hotel for a good price in nyc.. hope it doesnt go up. i wil be returning :)

Sep 7 2008 	Loved it!	The Roosevelt was perfect for my first visit to NYC! Beautiful hotel, convenient location, helpful staff, overall a wonderful experience. Then they sent a customer satisfaction survery (what a laugh) to which we replied very negetivly - but still no reply. We got an email to say that since we had posted negetive feedback they would be in touch - we are still waiting! The best laugh is that they still send me emails inviting us to 'visit again soon'!!! We have stayed in NYC several times but this is one place we will absolutly not be returning to - even if offered for free! Our next stay will be back to 'The Intercontinental - The Barclay' which justifies its 5 star rating.

Aug 29 2008 	not impressed	hotel was very nice but the staff were not helpful or friendly, i found them very rude, you are in a strange country and you want to ask questions they did not want to help or direct you in the right direction, i felt i was bothering them, i found the staff very snobbish.hotel was near shops which was great, the shower was not very good, room was very clean.i did not eat at the hotel, too expensive, i took food back to hotel in the evening, but when my room was cleaned, the cleaning staff left a card on my bed for me to see about room service and the prices, i take it they saw the food wrappers in the bin but it is my choice if i ate at the hotel or not.i would not go back to this hotel again, the view from the room was a tower block, but when i checked in was told i had a nice view over looking the street which was not true,i did leave a customer form saying how rude the staff were i guess they will just bin it, that is there attitude they just did not care. i payed decent money to stay at this hotel and i expected a good service which i did not get..eat at grand central station food court which was reasonable.take a trip to china town, sample the food which was fantastic and cheaptime square was an experience go when it is dark the lights are out of this world.i felt safe walking in the day and night, new york is a must to see designer clothes are cheaper and the trainers.would go back to ny but would stay in a different hotel.

Aug 28 2008 	Super hotel - great location	We just returned from a week in the Roosevelt and we loved it. Aug 28 2008 	Nice hotel nice location	Me and a friend stayed at the Roosevelt for 6 nights in August, and our first impressions were good. The hotel is in a good location (near Grand Central, NY Public library, 5th Avenue - good shops and about a 10 min walk to times square). As we are from England, we were not used to the hot climate, fortunately taxis were relatively cheap to get around. Checking in was quite simple although the receptionist was very unpleasant - he tossed our key across the desk and had a bad attitude. Additionally, the safe in our room was broken, but after calling security this was fixed promptly and the security guy also gave us free breakfast! (We were on a room only basis - breakfast is quite good but I would probably get sick of it everyday - we usually just went to cafes - cafe metro is quite good for breakfast and only about $5.) Additionally the hair dryer was broke in the room and this was never repaired.The cleaning service was quite good and the maids were friendly and actually took notice of the 'do not disturb' sign - this is quite often ignored in other hotels I have stayed in. The hotel rooms were average, we stayed in a 'petite room', 'petite' being true. The room included a large plasma TV with quite a few good channels - movie channels, MTV, BBC etc, and ironing facilities etc. You should also look into the cheapest way of getting to the hotel from the airport, from JFK we got ripped off and ended up paying $90 when the guy had told us it would cost $50. Another man running his private taxi business practically ran away with my suitcase in an attempt to rip us off. Yellowcabs are usually quite cheap for getting around so I'd probably suggest that. Another thing, is EVERYONE expects you to tip them, coming from a country were tipping is not often necessary I found this strange - one guy who gave us a piece of paper with how much luggage we had loitered round for a few minutes until we gave him some dollars, additionally restaurants sometimes add this onto your bill or state that 15-20% is sufficient. Points of interest I would recommend would be to see a Broadway show (we saw Mamma Mia which was excellent and funny), Statue of liberty, Empire state building (good view at night and that is when ques are shorter) top of the rockerfeller centre is good through the day as you get a great view of central park. Central park is a lovely place too and we spent a nice day just walking round, visited strawberry fields and went on the rowing boats near the boathouse. Restaurants I would recommend are Tavern on the Green in central park (outdoor and pretty with lanterns and live music, nice to end the night on a horse and carriage ride which is from $40), Ellen's stardust diner near the theatres in Times Square is quite good for younger people too, this is where all of the waitresses are trying to make it on broadway and serve and sing - the food isn't that good but it's a different experience and a lot of the child customers enjoyed it. Overall I would recommend the Roosevelt and I would definitely return. If you have any questions regarding the Roosevelt you may send me a message and I'd be happy to help.

May 19 2008 	My Tips for NYC	I had been looking to go back to NY for a while but all the deals for 6 nights were really expensive. I know many people rely on tips, but they were too aggressive with some people!FLIGHTI flew direct from Manchester to Newark with Continental. The plane was comfortable and the entertainment system on the way out was great (You could chose what you want when you want it), it wasn't so good on the way back.TRANSFERSIf you read the guides about getting to NYC from Newark it sounds complicated. In reality you buy a ticket for the NJ Transit train at the airport terminal before getting on any trains. You then jump on the airports train (Mono rail) to the airports station, you then connect to Penn Station and you are there! Its $15 single and takes 40 Min's in total. You can then buy a 7 day Metro card that covers the buses and Subway for $21.TIPSThe view from the ROCK is the best I have seen anywhere.Take the free tour of Grand Central Station and the New York Public library. They are both very good.

Nov 26 2009 	A Mixed Bag	We have just returned from 4 nights in The Standard Hotel in the Meatpacking district of New York City and found this hotel to be a very mixed bag. On the positive side, meatpacking is a vibrant lively area with great restaurants and up-market shopping and The Standard is located right in the heart of this. The hotel itself is beautifully designed, rooms are a little small but typical of NYC, but there are great views across the city. We had a room on the 11th floor and from our bath we could look out across the city, taking advantage of the floor to ceiling window.The bistro and the grill were both pretty good, standard American dining but definitely worth trying. Now for the major thing to be warned about...the picturesque lounge bar on the 18th floor closes to residents at 9pm and becomes a nightclub! That means that because it is located on the top floor, the sound travels right the way down through the whole building...on the night we arrived we were woked by throbbing bass at 2am, luckily we had ear-plugs that we could use. The funny thing about the lounge/club on the top floor after 9pm is that as a guest you are not allowed to go in! So you have to put up with the noise but can't join in, it is a little silly but i am sure they are making a large amount of money by hiring the space out. If you want a drink in the bistro after 11 also be warned it is extremely busy and you may struggle to be served. We did use room service and that was good, food arrived quickly and was exactly as ordered. Staff were also friendly and helpful, so no complaints there.

Nov 25 2009 	Will stay here again and again!!	We stayed here for 4 nights in October and the hotel is fabulous. Our room had dual views over the Hudson and The Empire State Building. Oct 28 2009 	Amazing end to our NYC trip....superb hotel.	We decided on splitting our NYC trip into 2...the first, we stayed Midtown, in a somewhat disappointing The MAve. And we were oh so pleased to have made The Standard in Meatpacking our last. We spent 3 nights in this UBER trendy hotel to finish off our fab NYC visit.The area: wow....I must start by saying that the Meatpacking District is so very cool, and has a trendy, underground feel to it. It may not be THE in-area right now (Hell's Kitchen is hotting up big time), but it is still the Meatpacking district, point. Nice shops, great restaurants (we frequented Pastis more than once), the High Line park is lovely and gives a great chance to explore the area. We really enjoyed exploring on foot and walked all the way down Bleecker Street until we hit Soho for great shopping and scene. We even went so far as to walk all the way from Brooklyn Bridge up through Tribeca then Soho and up to The Standard hotel. Walk, walk, walk....staying at this hotel puts you in a great position to explore by foot.The hotel staff: All the staff we encountered were extremely friendly and knowledgeable. I have read other reviews saying that they felt the staff would barely look up and offer assistance. I personally think though that some people confuse the hotel service you would expect to find in a 5 star chain to the service one simply must expect at a trendy, boutique-esque hotel. All staff were amazing. We had room service, bellboy bags to room, assistance at the front desk on a few occasions...each and every time, without fail, we were given friendly, cool service with a smile...not fake, not over the top...just what one would expect. No robots here...just staff with personality. The hotel: ooh la la...from it's truly unique exterior to it's super trendy interior, The Standard really knows how to put on a show. The design is supercool. The bright yellow table/bench combos adorn the entrance, leading to revolving doors, bringing you into a slick, sexy lobby. Round the corner are the pitch black elevators...quit complaining that they are too dark people! It's all about design. So you know...the elevators are pitch black, you are in darkness, apart from 2 adjacent video screens with a superb, ongoing digital video collage...I seriously loved the ride up and down to our 14th floor. The screens DO provide some light, so it's not like you are fumbling around in the dark. We arrive on the 14th floor, heading down the minimal corridor to room 1414. The numbers are embossed in HUGE, vertically, on the door itself, as well as on small plates next to the door (I wonder if they had to add those because the complainers couldn't 'see' the numbers on the doors originally). We enter the room and need a moment to compose ourselves because the view just takes our breath away. We see ALL of downtown, the Hudson River, Jersey City, Madame Liberty in the distance, High Line park below. The floor to ceiling, room wide, windows are just superb. And yes...people can see into the rooms so beware, unless you like to put on a show for those down below. The room itself is also quite simply amazing. We took a Deluxe King...perfect choice, room enough to swing quite a few cats, very clever use of space and design. The bed was very, very comfortable, with the loveliest squishiest pillows I have slept on in a long time. The bath was more than big enough for the 2 of us...and if you are into that kinda thing, 3 is still not a crowd in that tub. The closet space is more than plenty for a typical weekend away in New York...we solved the suitcase 'space' issue by putting our cases in the corner of the room on a table, voila...nothing worth complaining about. The toiletries are provided by Kiss My Face...hide them daily so you keep getting more to take back home, they are lovely!The ONLY 1 downside to our room was that on Saturday night, we actually wanted an early night, but there is a bar down the road which does have an outside area belting music till the early hours. Brass Monkey I think it is called. The sound is muffled, the room insulation is very good, but still, I did use earplugs to drown out the slight noise. The issue is solved very easily...just use earplugs, or go down and join the party. This would not put me off staying at the Standard again.All in all, I highly recommend this hotel. It's all about design, cool, great atmosphere, catering to couples/singles...not families (I secretly like that fact). I will most certainly, 100% be coming back for a stay when next in New York.

Oct 14 2009 	Sub-Standard.	This hotel looked great on the surface, good location, great views and nice amenities but once you dive deeper you'll find the appeal is only skin deep.A variety of issues meant our stay was cut short, we lost a night's sleep, a day out of our vacation and soon we were force to find a suitable hotel for the rest of our trip during a very booked week.Poor craftsmanship and maintenance meant scalding water came out of the bathtub, hot water out of the shower caused the smoke alarm to activate (with a disheartening lack of response to the alarm or our safety from the front desk) and bathroom design that causes shower water to wet the entire floor making it very slippery.Surprisingly for a newish hotel, the rugs were already filthy with stains, the weatherstripping around the wood wall feature was peeling off in the 3 rooms I was in, tiles were chipped and curtain rods broke... no insulation between rooms means you hear your neighbor moving their drapes. Hope you didn't bring a lot of clothes because there's virtually no closet space and about 3-4 hangers, make sure you get one at least with the four 8"x8" shelves.WC has no storage, no lock and a huge gap in the hinge side... meaning make sure there's toilet paper in there first since housekeeping doesn't replace it, and expect no privacy since the design and construction telegraphs every sound.Speaking of sound, don't stay on the "Superior" side if you want any rest, you'll be right above this gem of a noise maker called the "Brass Monkey" that's open till 4am. Yes that wonderful build quality I told you about before means you'll hear every hoot, holler and bass note that comes out of their outdoor section. You might get lucky with the noise in the "Deluxe" rooms further down on the other wing but don't bet on it, I could hear the racket from a 17th floor "Superior" room. Watch out for rooms near the elevator and ice machine, you'll hear them all night long as well.They have a restaurant and a bar but I never got to try either, we got turned away because it was booked for a private event and filled with overspill respectively. Note to hotel, tell your guests when it's booked so they don't rely on coming back for a bite.The staff tried to help but honestly, they don't have the tools to fix what's fundamentally wrong with this hotel. If you can deal with all of the headaches of this hotel, and there is A LOT OF THEM, about the only redeeming quality is the view.

Sep 20 2009 	Love-Hate	We loved this hotel at the same time as it made us really mad. The tiny room (over $600 a night with taxes) was uncomfortably small for two people but definitely the best tiny room weve experienced. However the queen bed, pushed into a corner, made sleeping uncomfortable for the inside personand ridiculously inconvenient when it came to getting up in the middle of the night. The big TV at the foot of the bed, in front of the huge window, seems gigantic in such a pint-sized room.However, design is everywhereevery little bit of this place is designed for visual interest. My two favorite features were the video collage in the elevators and the knitted cozies slipped over the steel stanchions outside. The location is lots of fun. Sep 4 2009	Great style location views	When planning our annual trip to New York, I wanted to get away from the midtown hotels and stay more towards Greenwich Village. We have walked around the Village numerous times,, but have always gotten lost, what with its narrow streets intersecting this way and that, without the perfect grid system of midtown streets. We also have been following the High Line project--the redevelopment of an old elevated railroad platform into a lovingly and cleverly designed landscaped walkway-- as well as the construction of the Standard Hotel straddling it. So when we discovered the Standard would be open during our planned visit, we eagerly booked there. We were able to get a good web-only rate similar to the soft opening rate the hotel initially offered.The Neighbourhood.  The hotel is located in the Meatpacking district just north of the West Village. It straddles the High Line and is quite an impressive sight, 18 stories tall. We first visited this area when the boutique Jeffrey opened on 14th St. a number of years ago . Back then the area truly did consist of mostly meatpacking facilities. A few of these still remain, but most have become designer shops, clubs, lounges and restaurants. The nightlife here is very active--weekdays and weekends we witnessed crowds at 2 am and later--people who require very little sleep and/or don't go to work until the afternoon, if at all. Over the course of our 6 day stay, we saw exactly 3 children in the area, all during daylight hours and none within the hotel itself. The hotel offers queen or king rooms only; 2 people maximum per room.The nearest subway stop is about a 5 minute walk away.The Hotel Public Rooms.There is a large outdoor seating area in front of the lobby, which is smallish but stylish, a bit retro looking. The elevators all have 2 unique video screens playing a mesmerizing continuously scrolling presentation, with music. There are several lounge spaces on the ground floor, both indoors and out, with the largest being outdoors under (and protected by) the High Line--very popular. The restaurant The Standard Grill is adjacent, also with indoor and outdoor seating. Not yet opened is the top (18th) floor lounge/club, which apparently will have pool, and is certain to be a hot spot once it opens in about a month. It will surely be a velvet rope type of place, and I would expect there may be difficulty (or at least a wait) for guests just trying to return to their rooms. Even now, over the weekend there was security at the elevators, asking for room keys and checking guest names from a list. There is a large gym on the 17th floor with fabulous views in 3 directions, including the Hudson River. There is no business center (but Wifi is free) or spa.The Guestrooms.Our web rate was for a Standard Queen, but we were upgraded to a south-facing Superior Queen, a slightly smaller room but with a better view. Apparently all the Standard rooms face north, where one gets a glimpse of the river. High Line and Empire State Building, but mostly one sees a large building being built one block north. From the south-facing rooms, there are virtually no buildings taller that the hotel, so one can clearly see Downtown, the southern tip of the High Line, much better views of the Hudson River, New Jersey and the Statue of Liberty. We were informed at check-in as well as via a letter delivered to the room that the floor-to-ceiling windows were non-reflective, so without your drapes drawn, people below can see EVERYTHING, and this apparently has been an issue, based on things we'd read online. Indeed, whenever we looked down at the High Line, there were always people staring up at the hotel.The room was not large, but I've seen smaller in New York, and things were designed to maximize space--a built-in seating area, 2 sides of the bed placed flush against the wall (the person with the stronger bladder should sleep against the wall). The colour scheme is black, white and beige. The flat screen HD TV froze a lot.The bathroom was tiled in black with a laboratory-like sink and counter fixture. The bath products were cleverly packaged. Very early TA reviews of the hotel mentioned the flooding situation involving the shower, and we bore witness to this in our room. The shower is not enclosed, with only a small glass partition between it and the sink. Only the water temperature can be controlled, not the volume (this is true of practically every hotel shower we've used for the past few years), so the water naturally flows out onto the floor, which is not sloped enough towards the drain. We learned quickly to form a dam using a towel (very large and fluffy by the way) to contain the water. Indeed, after showering, the driest place in the bathroom was in the bathtub, which was huge and open to the bedroom with shutters. The toilet was in a separate water closet.The Staff and Service.The staff was all quite young and stylish, courteous and helpful for the most part. Male staffers seem to outnumber the females. Our one exception was with an unfriendly room service attendant, but this was after midnight and he was doing double duty--taking an order on a mobile phone while delivering our order.This was a fun hotel in a fun location. It's not a 5 star place, nor does it strive to be, but it delivered on most fronts. Again, it's not a place for families with small children or friends who are not intimate with each other. or for business. Coming from Los Angeles, we think this Standard has more to offer than either of the LA Standards.

Aug 26 2009 	Not If You Need Your Sleep	all other elements of a hotel stay are secondary to getting a good night's sleep- and that's impossible at the standard: early morning hammering and drilling ruin an otherwise well-run establishment.the truly pointless aspect of this is that the construction work rarely takes more than a couple of hours to complete- hours that could just as easily occur in the afternoon when the overseas traveller, night-owl, or holiday-taker would be much less-likely to be disturbed. yet, despite countless complaints to clueless staff and management over a multi-month stay, the hammering begins again the next morning at 8am (and is once again completed before lunch). were it not for this pointless insensitivity to the basic needs of its guests, my review of the standard would be complimentary. but mismanagement at this level borders on the criminal.

Jul 17 2009 	Sexy Hotel; It's a Soft Opening	It's a very sexy hotel, design-wise. The rooms, though small, or really nicely appointed. Jul 16 2009 	Amazing style people location and service is the pinnacle.	In NYC on business, I usually stay at a different hotel based on where I need to be for work / events. Jul 12 2009 	Too much flash and no substance	I travel almost every other week and stay in a lot of hotels, and as a design and construction professional I do not believe I have ever stayed anywhere that misses the point of a hotel more than the Standard. Yes it is close to the nightlife, but that is a double edged sword as the the builder obviously cut corners on the glass selection to prevent all that noise below from interferring with your quiet time. I believe I have stressed the two good points. The rooms are so affected that I could go on and on, but some of the highlights are that the only place to use a blow dryer is in the wet room (which was the all in one bathroom). I believe most people know you shouldn't use a hair dryer standing in a wet area. At this hotel you have little choice. The toilet in a "closet" ont he opposite side of the hall had all the makings of a claustrophbic bowel movement. There wasn't even enough room in the the toilet room to house an additional roll of toilet paper. Jul 12 2009 	Amazing hotel which has great sense of fun with fantastic views	I picked The Standard Hotel as it is close to my Sister's place in New York and it's directly above the new High Line Park which is an amazing new park on an old elevated railway. You know what I mean, some scream 'business' or 'budget' or 'help i'm stuck in the 90's' but with The Standard there is none of that kind of aura. It's a place where you can be who you want to be and do what you want to do. Everything even down to the design of the rooms has a sense of fun about it (even some of the items in the Mini Bar)!My room had an amazing view down the Hudson towards The Statue of Liberty and downtown. While not being one of the biggest rooms, the clever layout and floor to ceiling glass made it seem spacious and roomy with a good sized and very comfortable bed and its own 'lounge area'. The Concierge even managed to get me a table at short notice for the newly opened and very popular Standard Grill which is superb. I also had free wi-fi which based on my stay at another NY hotel seems to be quite rare. As for downsides I don't think I could name any that I had during my stay. I had a really great time and have already recommended it to a couple of my friends. I'm looking forward to staying there next time I travel to New York!

I get what they were going for, mid-century/Danish, but it somehow misses the mark and feels more like the inside of an RV with strange bolsters and railing around the room. Jun 16 2009 	A bit dude but great sleeps	Stayed here for five nights, with my dog, who garnered far more attention than I did from the staff. For the most part, the staff was lovely, but I do concur with an earlier reviewer who referred to them as hipster. The housekeeping staff were all lovely and attractive and overly, far more friendly than some of the young front end people. Overall, the housekeeping staff was terrific! The rooms have a bit of a dorm room meets camper trailer feel to them. That said, I was paying the soft rate while they complete construction and have no complaints about that at all. The beds were very comfortable an the quality of linens was nice. I slept really well. But the white quilted blankets made me feel like I was in school and the seating area totally reminded me of camping when I was a kid. I would not be surprised if the table collapses into a bed. I do have one big complaint about this hotel. They need to seriously upgrade their product line of soaps and shampoos. They are also just a bit DUDE on that front. Spruce bubble bath? Ick! All the scents were very masculine. I'm not looking for super flowery either, but I don't want to come out of the bath smelling like a Christmas tree. The bubble bath and shower gel were a huge disappointment, especially given the massive bathtub. The packaging of all that stuff was also terrible. It looked like generic shampoos you might pick up at Walmart. They really need to upgrade that stuff, especially once they are off the soft rates and people are paying full price. The towels, however, are fantastic! Nothing like a massive bathsheet. A bathrobe would have been nice too. In general, I had a great stay and given where all my friends live, it was the perfect neighbourhood for me, but I'm not sure I would pay full price for one of these rooms. Jun 8 2009	OMG the VIEWS!	We were delighted by our short stay at the Standard. We reserved 2 standard queen rooms. We had to beg for the reservation since normally they have a two night minimum, but when I explained this was a special occasion (our daughter's 21st birthday), they were kind enough to make an exception. We couldn't get in on the soft opening deal of $195/night, but felt the $265/a night quoted price was pretty good for NYC. We were wowed by the contemporary decor that greeted us in the lobby. I had not been to NYC in 16 years, and was quite surprised by the friendliness of the staff, not even a molecule of snootiness--warm, friendly, fun, and helpful. We were blown away when we were told BOTH rooms had been upgraded in honor of our daughter's birthday. Our daughter was given a river view room that was mind-blowing. Although all rooms have floor to ceiling, wall to wall windows with amazing views, at the foot of her bed was a panoramic view of the Hudson river that she will never forget. Even the statue of Liberty was visible. The totally full moon and fireworks display rather added to the excitement of this awesome view in the evening. For New York standards, the room was nicely sized, with a nice contemporary table, huge tub, and rainforest shower. Big fluffy towels (lots of them), and an amazingly well stocked minibar were part of the charm. Our second room (upgraded to a standard King) had a great city view showcasing the Empire State Building. The bed was so comfortable, with wonderful linens. The flat screened TV, glass-walled rain forest shower (in the middle of the room) and comfy contemporary chairs (to position for staring out the window or using at the table) were nice touches as well. The Elevators--so fun! Cartoon/animated-like displays of "Wonder World" (hard to describe but a must-see) were whimsical, entertaining, and unique. Clearly this hotel does not take itself overly seriously as so many NY hotels do. The staff courteously accommodated every request--supplying shaving cream and toothpaste on request, and answering all questions regarding directions, travel times, etc. Room service breakfast no longer free and restaurant not yet open, but we ordered coffee and rolls and it was extremely reasonable and prompt. The only suggestion I would make is installing black-out linings behind the drapes (the sun REALLY makes itself known in the morning), but on second thought, who has time to sleep in while visiting the Big Apple? The hip meat packing district where the hotel is located is really convenient in terms of being in a central location and very "mid town buzzy" and young. I highly recommend this hotel. although apparently all the views are great, if at all possible, splurge and get a room with a river view, it's spectacular and worth it for a memorable experience in New York.

Jun 6 2009 	Alright	Stayed here for four nights in May.Rooms are very nice and the location is perfect, very close to bars, nightclubs and shopping as well as to the quaint West Village.Our room had black hairs in the bathtub that weren't removed on our second night either but upon complaining they did clean it very well.Breakfast that is being sent to the rooms while the restaurant is being build is average.Not too sure about the hipster staff who seem to be hired on looks only and appear as if though they are doing you a favour when you ask for assistance etc.

Feb 8 2009	Sexy Showers at the Standard	Having visited The Standard in Miami, I've been looking forward to seeing what The Standard in NYC would offer in a town full of high-end unique hotels. The hotel is still not complete and won't be for some time, I guess, but do not be afraid to book a room in the meantime. I didn't hear or see any evidence of the construction once inside the building, which is pretty impressive. And the staff does everything it can to make your stay comfortable. I was particularly impressed with the concierge--she actually KNEW the area unlike so many other concierges who take up space behind a desk and merely recommend people to the same 2 restaurants. I was trying to figure out what to do with my afternoon and she knew where I could get a haircut, where the best art gallery was, what the exhibits were like at a small nearby museum, what spas were good, where I should get a drink and where I should get dinner all within the neighborhood and her recommendations were all spot on. Management clearly understands good staffing.That leads me to the best thing about this hotel--its location. This area is my favorite part of NYC. The restaurants and clubs are plentiful and good. And the buildings aren't so high. It's authentic NYC. And to be able to walk back to the hotel after experiencing it all is a plus for me.My room at The Standard was good, although not super unique. But absolutely no complaints. Floor to ceiling windows create the view, a well-appointed and comfortable bed make for a good night of sleeping. As others have mentioned, the shower is separated from the bedroom by floor to ceiling clear glass, which I thought was pretty damn sexy. (Too bad the shower's design seems a little off as water was pouring into the bathroom and into the living room rug. I didn't mind it but I felt bad for the housekeeping staff.) I'll definitely be heading back when it's complete to see what else it has to offer.
