Oct 26 2009 	Honestly? For a St Regis it was very disappointing	I stayed in St Regis halfway through my trip in NYC. My mum & her husband were on an official trip to NYC and since there was an extra room in the Presidential Suite they asked my sis & me to join them.I must say up front that decor-wise, this isn't my style of hotel. I prefer contemporary, tropical, industrial, quirky designs over the gilt gold old classical decor any time, but decor-wise aside, I must admit I was very disappointed with the overall service at the St Regis. Yes, the rooms were large and comfortable, and the beds heavenly. We had a view of Central Park from the living room and that was very cool. The bathroom was also very large but the shower area was quite small and cramped and poorly ventilated, trapping a lot of stifling steam during a hot shower. I didn't spend much time in the living area but the flat screen tv camouflaging as a mirrored frame was a pretty cool idea. I also liked the toiletries in the bathroom and people-watching in the lobby.But aside from the first Butler (Josef) who was very helpful, the rest of them didn't seem to like their jobs very much. One middle-aged lady butler didn't seem to know how to clear up the dining table properly and breakfast we pre-ordered the night before showed up half an hour late (it was also pretty mediocre). My mum woke up the first morning to find coffee and cookies on a tray and she thought they were wonderfully efficient, until she noticed that the cups were all dirty, the pot was empty and it was actually YESTERDAY afternoon's coffee. When she called the Butler all they said was "Oh, you should have called housekeeping" without even apologizing. Considering they make up the room everyday and there should have been a turn down service in the evenings, shouldn't they notice these things? Plus, shouldn't the Butlers come in to check once in awhile instead of waiting to be called? Frankly after the second day, we didn't see a single butler and a broken glass that was there on the FIRST DAY we checked in was still there on the day we checked out! And they didn't replace used dirty glasses with clean ones. If we didn't wash them on our own, we wouldn't have clean glasses at all. Honestly, for the money one pays to stay at the Presidential Suite at the St Regis (or in ANY room at the St Regis for that matter), this shouldn't be the case at all. I was also shocked to find that housekeeping attempted to poorly hide the bedcovers behind the curtains! I really don't know why they didn't just fold it neatly and place it in the almost empty armoir instead. They also seemed to want to get their jobs done in a hurry and kept hovering outside the room and appearing every fifteen minutes even though the do not disturb sign was on and we kept telling them that there was a meeting taking place and to come back later. Other than that, the tv in the bedroom was actually quite small, and wouldn't come out properly from the armoir. You also couldn't turn the aircond or heating on permanently, it was either on AUTO or OFF, and left the room feeling very very warm during the night while we were sleeping. And on the last night, housekeeping didn't even put the drinking water out at all. I was also a bit annoyed with the much too large bathroom rug that was too thick to allow the bathroom door to open without bunching it up. The lift was also kind of small and very rattle. Probably time for an upgrade or serious maintenance. Oh, and if paying that much money for a room wasn't enough, they charge you for internet too! I've paid $165 for a room in NYC before and got free internet even then! Also, there were issues with the key swipe every single night. Even when we went down to get it reset, it still didn't work! We were so exhausted to go down again that thankfully the adjoining room was open and we went into the suite from there.Now if I were paying $100 a night and had to deal with these issues, I would understand, heck, we wouldn't even have a butler in the first place. But I have stayed in cheaper hotels with better service! And like I said earlier, for a St Regis, these issues should not happen at all. And I have been lucky enough to accompany my mum on some trips and even in China the butler always comes in to check to make sure everything is alright and the room gets a full cleaning the minute everyone leaves and is in tip top condition when we get back.That is not to say that everyone in the hotel was a horror though. Nov 22 2008 	Excellent but old-fashioned	Looking at its website before arriving, I was worried about not liking the St Regis. For this style of hotel in NY, I still prefer the Peninsula but it is a very close race.Right from the moment I arrived, everyone was unfailingly friendly and polite: nothing was too much trouble, and every single person who met me greeted me with a cheerful smile. The butler service was much more practical and useful than other hotels I have stayed at: the butler was very friendly and seemed to take a great personal pride in sorting out whatever you requested. Room service breakfast was excellent, and good value compared to other NY five star places.The rooms themselves do the very best they can around the old bones of the hotel. They are decorated in a clean, classical style--my Astor Suite was in a muted yellow with silk wall panels, while my colleague's Grand Luxe room was in a light duck egg blue. Both were good sizes and well laid out, with classical marble bathrooms that are a good size and well-equipped. The Astor Suite suffered from the very small windows you get on the top floors of the building, but in return for that the views were good. For me, given the hotel's short height and location, none of the views are spectacular: just nice views up and down the grand streets. The Grand Luxe room was much brighter, but you only really saw the fronts of other buildings from the windows.All the facilities worked excellently, as expected at this level. Good high-speed internet and excellent climate control in both rooms. Jun 20 2008 	Exceeded all expectations	Booked two nights at the St. Regis for my wife's birthday midweek using Starwood points. Jun 15 2008 	Absolute Luxury	It was our 10th wedding Anniversary and I wanted to do something special for my beautiful wife so I booked a room at the St. Regis for one night on the Friday of Memorial Day weekend. I booked the Astor Suite for our stay. I also booked a custom massage for my wife and myself. The Concierge was able to get us a dinner reservation at Daniel and everything was in place for a wonderful trip. We drove in from Connecticut and arrived at the St. Regis at 12:15 p.m.. We took advantage of the valet parking and our bags were taken care of smartly by the very professional doormen working the sidewalk. We we're greeted very warmly and we followed the porter inside to the magnificent lobby. We proceeded to guest registration to check-in. I was greeted warmly by the woman checking us in and she told us because of our early arrival, our room was still occupied. However, she said she had a very nice room for us, a very, very, nice room. She handed me the key cards to our room and we were shown around the hotel by a very charming young woman. We were then taken to the elevator and we proceeded to the 18th floor. We got off the elevator went through the french doors, turned left and proceeded to the end of the hall and there was our room. Room 1803 is also known as the Imperial Suite and we were led inside by our butler. The Imperial Suite was gorgeous. You walk into a marble floored foyer with fresh flowers in a vase on the table. We turned left and proceeded to a beautiful bedroom with french antiques and crystal chandalier over the bed. The marble master bathroom was exquisite and spacious. On the other side of the foyer was the living room with two large circular windows. The oval window looked out to the west on 5th Avenue and the Peninsula Hotel across the Avenue. The other round window faced north with a breathtaking view up 5th Avenue with the trees of Central Park verdant in the distance. Next to the living room was an elegant dining room with a six foot round mahogany table surrounded by six elegant chairs. Off the dining room was a full kitchen with granite countertops. Beyond the dining room was a rich paneled study in the most handsome, masculine wood with a beautiful wood desk and chair. The Imperial Suite also had a total of two and one half baths, four flat screen TVs, crystal chandaliers in every room and luxurious empire furniture. I kidded my wife that I felt like french royalty in this fabulous suite. I could have sat on the padded window seat looking out over Central Park for hours. We left and walked over to MoMA. After about three hours at MoMA, we returned and dressed in only our slippers and robes went down to the Spa and were treated royally with our massages. My masseuse was wonderful. My wife reported that her masseur was also fantastic. We returned to our suite and I decided to take a bath. It was a perfect compliment to the massage. I was totally relaxed. We got dressed for dinner and the doorman hailed us a cab and we were whisked away to Daniel for dinner. What a fabulous restaurant. The food, the presentation and the service were all incredible. After dinner, we decided to walk back to the hotel since it wasn't that far and it was a beautiful spring evening in the city. We returned to the St. Regis and walked into the King Cole Bar for a drink. After a round of Red Snappers and catching up with my cousin the artist and musician who met us there, I told my cousin that he had to see our room. He had been to many 5 star hotels throughout Europe and he said he had never seen such a great suite. After he left, my wife and I sat on the padded window seat and took in the city from our big round window. The bed was like sleeping on a cloud and our bedroom was quiet and peaceful. We awoke the next morning and unfortunately had to check out. What a fabulous experience. We will never forget our stay at the St. Regis

Jun 13 2008	Glad I experienced it; would choose a different hotel next time	My husband booked this hotel for my birthday (a special one); he knew I wanted to experience the hotel at some point in my life. He tried to book a suite but was told that there were none available but not to worry---the room would be the best of the rest. He also wanted tickets to South Pacific and was told that the seats, though terribly expensive, would be the best in the house. He also asked to book a private boat for a Sunday morning Hudson River ride...When we arrived, the greetings and help from the doormen and front desk staff just weren't what we expected from this class of hotel. (I had just stayed at the Ritz Central Park South the month before, where the service was absolutely 5 star, and I could see the difference immediately). The room the butler brought us to faced a wall. We asked for another, and they offered a far better room, but at that point, I was wishing we had booked the Ritz. As we vacillated, the butler said the Madison Suite would be available in a few hours if we wanted to wait. So we did.The Madison Suite was spacious, with a foyer, separate living room, and two baths. It was spotless and really quite lovely with all the old architectural details. No complaints at all. Maid service during the day was excellent; the room was always pristine when we returned. (At night, they always missed at least one thing..we stayed 3 nights total.)When we picked up the tickets for the show, they were *not* the best seats in the house. They were in the loge, not in the orchestra. My husband said no to them, which caused a bit of fluster. Ten minutes later, someone called the room saying there had been a mixup and the seats were now 500 dollars less, far more acceptable. So in the end, we experienced the show and loved it, but this is the kind of thing that adds up to a disappointing hotel experience overall...Also, no one ever followed up on the boat trip. Similarly, everyday service was always polite and friendly but spotty. Sometimes someone would be at the door, greeting you and pushing it open, other times you would have to wrestle with it (it's heavy) yourself. Sometimes someone would be at the elevator to ask you which floor; most of the time, not.It *was* nice to stay in a place with such history, built the way nothing is built nowadays, and I'm really glad I did, but I wouldn't stay here again. In that location, and for that price point, the service at the Ritz was far superior.

Jan 31 2008 	Recommendation Depends on What You Are Looking For	First the pluses: The St. Regis is well located on Fifth Avenue near Tiffany's and other high end shops. It is a very short walk to Central Park and a five minute walk to Rockefeller Plaza. The beds are comfortable, the room size is quite good and it is a Grande Dame New York hotel property.Now for the the mediocre to minuses:Our two rooms looked out onto brick walls. One room had very little natural light and the other had virtually no natural light at any time of day. When booking the room, I noted to the St. Regis reservation clerk that I had seen an advisory on Trip Advisor that some rooms looked out on brick walls with no natural light. As this trip was a gift to my parents I told the agent that it was important to me that their room, at least, had some kind of view. I was assured that at $1,100.00 per night per room (and as a Starwood Preferred Guest) I was getting superior rooms with some sort of view. It was disappointing for me when that did not happen although some may not be concerned by that.Also, the service was only "good" and not the "excellent" I would expect paying the rack rate of $1,100.00 per night. For example, The St. Regis prides themselves on providing butler service. Personally (and this is another case where personal judgement comes in), I did not find having a butler terribly useful. For me they really just became someone else to tip (and the expected tip, as a per cent of room rate, was high). Our butler was polite but essentially just showed us around the room as a bus boy normally would do. They did offer to serve coffee or tea in the morning as part of our wake up call which is a nice idea. However, as I was travelling with my young daughter I asked if she could have a hot chocolate instead. The butler advised that I would have to make that arrangement through room service at a charge of something in excess of $10.00. At $1,100.00 per night, I think the hotel could have been flexible enough to offer hot chocolate for the wake up call. However, I will leave that up to the reader to decide. For me it was a niggly item that at this price point should not happen. Also, our room rate included a bowl of fresh fruit but on arrival we only had an empty bowl. Not a big problem especially since the butler said the bowl would be filled right away. However, it ended up taking two reminder calls and, even at that, the fruit did not arrive until the next afternoon. Again, just a niggly but one I don't expect at that price point. Butlers will also do a complimentary shoe shine overnight, and will iron up to two garments per day gratis. We did not need those services so there was not advantage to us there, but I recognize others may find that service useful (although with or without butlers most hotels at this price point offer at least the complimentary shoe shine and the expected butler tip at the end of the trip would have more than covered the cost of having a garment or two ironed).Finally, the food at the hotel is mediocre and, with the exception of the bar which has a beautiful mural that is worth taking a look at, the central restaurant suffers from poor lighting and an overall bland feel. To those choosing to stay at the hotel I would recommend eating meals elsewhere (even the highly touted afternoon tea was uninspired). Thanks to the great location there is a variety of very good restaurants and eateries including several that offer high tea.So there you have it. I have nothing terrible to say, it was just below expectations. On my next visit to New York, I will seek a hotel in the same locale but will forego the butler in favour of a room with a view and natural light.

Dec 12 2007 	You have to love the St. Regis	The St. Regis truly sets the standard for hotel stays in New York City. Even the Ritz Carlton feels like a significant step down after staying here. Although it is very expensive, the hotel really does deliver with service that goes beyond the offerings of other luxury hotels. They tend to be decorated in a more opulent Victorian fashion as well (compared to other NYC hotel rooms that generally have a contemporary feel). Best of all, each room is assigned to a butler who will bring up tea or coffee, or help you with anything you need. The only negative experience I have ever had here (other than the price) is that the last time I asked, they did not have an ATM in the hotel, which seemed a bit odd and was a bit inconvenient. But, that is a small price to pay in my opinion as there is always an ATM within a block or so in NYC.

Jun 19 2007 	Soothing Perfection	Truth be told we sometimes balk at paying over $1000 for a few hours kip, but we were escaping distraught from the hideous Hudson hotel and thought we would treat ourselves, and see if the St. Regis lived up to it's price tag (and reputation.)Our stay didn't start off very well. No one met us with our bags at the door. We had to queue at check-in (this should have been a far slicker affair). A lady who had pushed in front of us gestured for us to go ahead . The rather surly girl at reception asked us whether it was actually our turn, which I thought was extremely rude, (us being British and never queue jumping). She didn't seem capable of smiling, so check in got a thumbs down. It was an early morning escape from the Hudson and our room wasn't ready. We went to have tea in the breakfast room. The service was extremely slow. I had to go and ask the maitre d if anyone would serve us, and she didn't seem bothered that i felt the need to ask. 10 minutes later, and no waiter in sight. Add to this plentiful decibels of drilling and construction noise (for the new Alain Ducasse Restaurant opening there) and we again decided to flee into the much quieter new york streets.The communal areas are OK, a little bit small, but you become accustomed to them.BUT that was the bad. The good was that once we were finally ensconsed in our bedroom we were delighted. As soon as you leave the ground floor and enter the upper corridors, serenity, taste and an immaculate cleanliness abound. Our room must have been newly furnished, as I had never seen such a pristine hotel room. The bedlinen couldn't have been softer, and in the bathroom, everything was perfect. It was even possible to have a shower with out the rest of the bathroom steaming up an iota. Our personal butler George was super efficient and eager to please, and made us feel very at home. Even our maid was beautifully turned out and went about our turn-down service with an unhurried grace that was quite beguiling.A few details in the room weren't quite right (the chandelier didn't work, there was no room service menu) but these were trifles compared to the quality of everything else.The concierge had a few gems...he directed us to a gallery which is selling a picture from "that crazy guy, you know the one that paints the sun" (Van Gogh), and recommended a restaurant on the basis that it was "not one where people go to compare their clothes" - a profound man, and indeed his recommendation for us was spot on.OK long review but the short of it is...service mixed, you've seen a better lobby and dining areas, but the rest is perfection and worth ever penny.

Jun 18 2007 	Error prone luxury	In a super quiet oasis of Beaux Arts luxury in midtown Manhattan we experienced an error prone stay. After gratefully receiving an early check in and a spacious room we received a telephone call not to use the bathroom because there was a sewer problem which would be fixed "in a little while". Meanwhile we could go across the street to the Sony Center to use the bathroom. However, I was not feeling all that well and had to stay in our room waiting to be told the problem was over. After four hours we telephoned and were told it was all right now. I do not know if we would ever have been notified.In the evening, still not feeling well, I ordered room service and was told the "24 hour room service" would open at 7 pm. When I finally was able to order most of the items on the menu were not available due to " a problem in the kitchen".  Meanwhile we attempted to find the Silver Sea cruise representative desk and were sent from one floor to the next looking for him. No one seemed to know where he was or when his desk was open.At breakfast the service in the dining room was forgetfull: toast but no bread plates or butter, an unasked for glass of truly awful carrot-ginger juice, a long wait for everything. Then when we checked out we were charged again for the breakfast, although at check-in we had verified that our rate included breakfast. After all these inconveniences we were not offered any complimentary items or compensation, which would have, perhaps, overcome the need to write this negative review of a truly beautiful old-world hotel.

May 30 2007 	Pleasant if stuffy	In NY for business, I stayed at the St Regis for about a month in total. Not just once or twice either. And returned as if nobody noticed, despite the careful folding and two or three layers of wrapping. Contrasts with a far cheaper hotel I stayed in in HK where my casual shirt came back unexpectedly with a missing button replaced and nicely sewn on.Breakfast was excellent, and an exceptionally pleasant way to start the day. All up, I can recommend it as a pleasant if stuffy retreat from the hectic city without, but don't take your good shirts.

Apr 29 2007 	What do you get for $725 per night?	We booked three nights at the St. Regis in January and, like other reviewers, found the hotel well situated with rooms furnished with comfotable beds, fine linens, and luxurious amenities. The comments about the hotel's tight lobby and rooms are all accurate, but what is most disturbing about a hotel at this price point is the disappointing service we experienced. Here are just a few examples - Upon check in, we were informed that we would be provided with a bottle of wine and cheese platter in honor of a special occasion. During our stay, this never arrived. We also dined in the hotel's restaurant for breakfast and afternoon tea. The service during both did not impress. To the hotel's credit, the tea was delicious, but we were unable to finish all the sweets and asked for a box to take them to our room. The waiter offered to deliver them and we accepted this offer. The sweets did not arrive until several hours later and we charged for them at checkout. After two nights at the St. Regis, we decided to leave the hotel early and see if the similarly-priced Penninsula would deliver a better experience (it did - see review). Because the St. Regis failed to deliver the type of service we expected, we will choose another hotel when we return to NYC.

Apr 2 2007	Excellent Hotel	Just returned from NYC, having spent 4 nights at St. Regis, and we are already planning our return trip. Rooms are large, and although the decor is traditional (Empire), all modern convenience (also hygiene and maintenance) are facilitated.Areas are not large or sweeping (if this is you thing, Four Seasons has a large contemporary feel, which contrasts starkly with the food portions in their French Restaurant, (but that's for another review!) , located in same area), but intimate. Mar 18 2007 	An Elegant Past for a Modern Present	We spent two nights at the flagship St. Regis hotel in New York City in February 2007. What a wonderful stay  wed go back again in a minute. This hotel boasts a kind of hushed elegance that strikes just the right counterbalance to the hustle and bustle of New York City. The location, on Fifth Avenue in the mid-50s, is far enough away to avoid the crowds of the theater district but close enough to make getting around simple and straightforward. The lobby and public spaces are both grand and intimate and the hallways are hushed and elegant. The flowers and fine decoration everywhere make it seem the height of luxury. The hotels layout, design, service and amenities are all as top-notch as you would expect. The highlight of our stay was the room. We were upgraded to an Astor Suite and greatly enjoyed the extra space. The rooms are traditional, but with modern amenities and the result is a nice blend of both elegance and technology that is not an easy thing to pull off in a hotel room. The St. Regis succeeds very well in this regard, probably because it has always been a high-end hotel and changes made during the renovation simply updated what was already there. Were not sure if they added soundproofing during the renovation or if the hotel has always been so quiet: either way its a truly relaxing escape, with no outside sounds to interfere with the wonderful ambiance of the rooms. The front desk service, housekeeping and concierges are all excellent. We particularly enjoyed the food and beverage presentations, complimentary pressing and shoe shines and no problem attitude of the wonderful butler service. The only drawback to our stay was the service in the restaurant and bar. Were Four Seasons people and were accustomed to service in the bar and restaurant being one of the highlights of our stay at those properties. Despite the elegance and luxury of the St. Regis, the bar service was perfunctory at best and the breakfast service was slow and mostly unfriendly. Thats a shame, because the space (even with the current construction in the restaurant) is beautiful. We didnt sit in the bar itself because the small space was overflowing with people (we sat in the lower bar/restaurant area instead), but it looked very nice and wed recommend at least seeing it during your stay at this hotel. This is not a hotel for families on vacation in New York City: its a more refined and elegant space than the typical tourist hotel. Its probably also not a hotel for serious business travelers who need service beyond their rooms: the business center is a dark room off the staircase with what looks like discarded furniture and very little privacy. This is a hotel for people looking for an elegant, luxurious, relaxing place to stay in the heart of New York City. If thats what you want, and youre willing to splurge to get it, this is the hotel for you.

Aug 8 2006 	A Special Experience	First of all, unless you're willing to spend an outrageous sum of money simply to have a once-in-a-lifetime type of experience, don't even think of staying here. Like the decor and service, the prices are over the top. I paid $600 per night, and that was with a AAA discount on a summer weekend. Cocktails in the King Cole Bar run $15-$20. Room service breakfast is $30, before the service charges and taxes. --BUT--it's completely worth it. This is not simply about a luxurious place to leave your bags, lay your head, and have an evening cocktail. The St. Regis is a representation of a lifestyle that most of us can only afford on an infrequent splurge, if at all. These are guest rooms straight out of Versailles and staff for whom service is a career, not a stopover job. The location, at 5th Avenue and 55th St., is right in the middle of prime shopping and close to Central Park and Rockefeller Center. The Theatre District is a short cab ride or moderate stroll away. The rooms are something special, with ornate [but not overly so] decor including half-canopies on the beds, plush carpeting, huge bathrooms [by New York standards], good-sized closets, and padded silk wall coverings. My room was done in soothing and highly attractive muted tones of steel blue and mint green. I understand there are a couple of color schemes. There's also a "command center" at the bed, which will allow you to control all the lights in the room, adjust the air/heat, play different types of music, look up hotel/tourist information, and page your butler. [Each floor has a personal butler assigned who will take care of your every wish. You'll be taken up to your floor by the front desk staffer, where you'll be greeted by your butler at the elevator.] I would definitely recommend spending the extra $50 or so per night and getting the deluxe room, which includes a sitting area. The sitting area turned out to be a comfortable silk sofa, nice armchair and a coffee table with a large live orchid. There's also an end table with a selection of treats such as fresh fruit, nuts, mineral water and chocolates [complimentary]. The service can't be faulted--two items are allowed for complimentary pressing and they will be returned by the butler with a hand-written note. Luggage is handled extremely efficiently and every request is seen to promptly. They didn't drop the ball on anything during my entire stay. There's also an e-butler who can handle pre-arrival requests by e-mail--a nice, convenient touch.The King Cole Bar is legendary as the birthplace of the Bloody Mary [originally the Red Snapper] and the famous mural. Service here is also top-notch; easy-going but professional. The room is smallish, but in a cozy way with comfortable seating and expertly-made cocktails. The restaurant is open for all meals--didn't eat there, but it's a nice room with large windows. There are also a couple of lounges in small rooms off the lobby with intimate seating groupings, high ceilings and beautiful antique furniture. If you require a sweeping view, this may not be the place for you. The park-view rooms at the Ritz-Carlton may be better. But everything else about the St. Regis is absolutely superb.

Aug 2 2006 	Curious?? Is the High Price worth it???	CURIOUS?? Why would you spend thousands of Australian Dollars to stay in an Astor Suite at the St Regis? I was!! -along with 2 female Aussie friends I saved my money so that we could book an Astor Suite for 3 nights furing a New York Visit that formed part of a 5 week Europe and America Dream Vacation.So.... Is it worth the expense?? EVERYONE Should Live the High Life and Experience the St. Regis! This venue didn't disappoint - but lived up to its reputation of Luxury with Refined Understated Elegance. Like me, if never having stayed in a venue in this price range you may be very curious what it is that a venue like this could possibly offer that would make it worth the high price? Well, let me try to explain our experience.... On arrival we were warmly greeted by reception and escorted to our suite -(A lovely personal touch!) where we were introduced to our butler who returned within 10 minutes of our arrival with complimentary cheese and fruit platter and a steaming pot of coffee! As I relaxed on the gorgeous french antique style lounge, absorbed the luxurious but elegant decor and surfed the 100+ tv channels on the large flat screen tv - all thoughts of lost airport luggage, shopping and tourist attractions were put aside - One of our party opted for a soak in the deep marble tub (filled with Italian Aqua Di Parma luxury Bath Salts) - relaxing under the light of the bathroom chandelier while watching the large flat screen tv mounted above the bath! My other friend curled up on luxurious crisp egyptian cotton sheets with a feather pillow and a complimentary fashion magazine as our butler arranged for our luggage to be unpacked, our clothing pressed and our shoes shined. Within the hour we had settled and found our new home for the next 3 days...  Despite the obvious attractions of 5th Avenue and New York City being right on your doorstep the St. Regis old world elegant charm very quickly took hold and we were reluctant to spend much of our 3 day visit away from the venue! The St. Regis is an experience that everyone should STOP to enjoy! By all means, on a tourist visit to New York - perhaps stay in another cheaper standard 5 star Hotel as a base for day trips (eg. Waldorf Astoria, & Times Square Marriot was also nice and great locations) - but factor into your visit a couple of nights at this more exclusive venue to allow the opportunity to stop and relax in New York City away from the crowds and the traffic and the hustle and bustle of life.Do as we did and save the extra funds required -and splurge on the experience. Sip Champange for Breakfast, visit the day spa, enjoy the room service, appreciate the twice daily servicing of your room by house-keeping, the turndown service, the daily complimentary delivery of fresh roses and fruit & pastry platters, and enjoy the friendly but non obtrusive pampering from the hotel service staff, At the end of our booked stay we reluctantly checked out to transfer over to the Waldorf Astoria. During dinner that evening we reviewed our St.Regis Experience and realized we now had answered the question commonly asked by family members and friends who had learnt of the cost of our booking - , " Why would you spend so many thousands of dollars on 3 nights of accomodation at a Hotel? (Aus $2800 per night) How can it possibly be worth it?? " As we sadly farewelled the St. Regis - the answer was a clear and unaminous YES it was worth it! Every Aussie Dollar was well spent! It wasn't really any longer so much a question of whether this famous Hotel was worth it but rather - more the statement that WE are worth it!EVERYONE deserves and should take the opportunity to experience such a luxurious escape from the reality of daily living.So Save up for an experience that will give you a taste of life at a higher level... As one of my friends commented - " I felt really uncomfortable when I arrived....not being used to such luxury and over the top 'Tiffany silver service!' - On departure her comment was - "I now feel so different - very comfortable with Chandeliers in the bathroom! This experience has made me feel like a Princess, stretched my comfort Zone, my expectations and desire to achieve-I now feel like I could own the place!" That made it Worth it! - Having had but a small taste of lifestyles of the 'Rich and Famous" - might just help propel these 3 young single Aussie girls on to greater levels of personal & career success- Because we have now developed the taste for the finer things in life ! Not sure you can justify the price tag??? Take it from us - You ARE worth it!!!

When it was not delivered after an hour, we contacted the front desk and were told that our new butler would be arriving soon. Sep 11 2005	Luxury at the Reeg!	For Valentine's Day last year, my boyfriend treated us to a night at the St. Regis, such a decadent thing for 2 New York locals! Jul 28 2005	Absolute Perfection	Wow where to start?!!? I initially booked a Grand Deluxe room through the SPG Gold prefered guest line and recieved a very good rate at only $620 a night. Jun 27 2005	Unparalleled elegance comfort and service!	My husband and I just spent 3 days at the St. Regis for our 5 year Anniversary and we were beyond impressed. They were all perfectly open and looked like velvet. I even took them home with me so I can continue to enjoy them. The room was elegant but cozy and very well appointed. The location was a perfect home-base for all the sight-seeing we did and the concierge desk was most helpful for anything we needed.The turndown service can't be beat. Slippers on either side of the bed (his and hers), bottles of mineral water, and fresh ice in the bucket. Fresh fruit and chocolates in the room and a well-stocked bar were another plus. We had breakfast in the room one morning and the food was excellent, especially the pancakes. Dec 28 2004	Confusion meets Luxury	First for the Positives:-Very nice and descriptive web page.-Adequate selection of accomodations and competitve and corressponding prices.-Courteous front desk and lobby personnel.-Beautiful and awe inspiring room furnishings.-Superb location Negatives:Well, I can't really put the negatives in bullet form but I can state them properly in a paragraph. I initially booked a Deluxe King room in the Taste of Luxury package for around $650 a night, and the fourth night I was told would be free. But when I called to re-confirm they rudely stated that I was mistaken and that the fourth night was not free. This really ticked me off, so I faxed a copy of the rate details of the room over to the Executive Offices of the hotel, in this fax it showed them that the fourth night was in fact free. So then within 20 hours the Executive assistant Ms. Kim, called me to tell me that they will gladly honor my rate. Then the next day I called to re-confirm my reservation and was told very rudely again that my reservation had been canceled and that I had to wait until the morning to call back and re book. Then I called the Preffered guest reservation line and confromted them with my problem and was told that my reservation was NOT cancelled. So from there I told her that I needed proper compensation and was again instructed to contact Customer service in the morning.After this fiasco I must say that I enjoyed the trip except for the parts before my checking in to the hotel. Dec 6 2004 	Great location 	I last stayed at the St Regis nearly 10 years ago, and returned last month (November 2004). The butler on your floor brings complimentary tea/coffee and there are 2 complimentary clothes items pressed per person. They even provided decaffeinated tea at 4.30 a.m. when we were wide awake with jet lag. (What is the protocol with these butlers - is one supposed to tip them every time?) However, I was disappointed with the public rooms; in particular, there was no comfortable place to have coffee. We had invited someone to join us for coffee and were directed to a table in the dining room where we had not long before eaten breakfast. I inquired about the bar and they said it would be possible to bring the coffee through there, but on inspection, the bar area was dark & uninviting so we stayed in the dining room.We were leaving New York on a evening flight from La Guardia and I requested a late check out. This presented a problem until I offered to pay for half a day, when the problem disappeared. I think that hotels are entitled to expect payment for use of the room in such circumstances, especially at busy times (this wasn't such a time) but I do think that if they are being paid, then a hotel of this standard ought to service the room and they did not. (Especially as twice daily service is included in the full day rate - so surely one room service should be included for half a day)

The only gripe was that the TV's are a bit small.On my birthday, the hotel manager had a 1/2 bottle of Taittinger champagne delivered to the room. Oct 3 2009 	Too far from the heart of New York	The main issue we have with this place is that it's not a motel / hotel set up - it's run by private owners and basically there are only 3 rooms spread throughout the terrace (not the entire terrace like what we thought was the case). Location is too far from heart of new york. While i wouldn't say it's dangerous, it's a silent brisk walk back from the train station each night and a sigh of relief when we finally get into the room. Our room was absolutely fine and clean overlooking a very quiet courtyard so I was extremely relieved! We explored the public areas of the hotel which are absolutely beautiful . Nov 23 2009 	distinguished manhattan hotel - needs some updating	Stayed in one bedroom suite, which was pretty big (not just by NYC standards either) first, the bad:Bathroom had very little counter space, just the sides od the sink and the bathroom itself was small considering the size of the room. It was on, i could hear it, but cold air (even cool air) wasnt coming from either unit.Had cocktails at peacock alley and while they were friendly, the service was SO slow. it wasnt even very busy (it was much later than chocktail hour & dinner) and even having our waters refilled or getting a second glass of wine took so long, we just decided to leave early.The good: even though the hotel was busy (they said it was booked at full capacity) check-in was quick and efficient and the clerk was very friendly. the location of the hotel was perfect for me - i had a meetings at a building mere steps away and there's great shopping just a few blocks away.the room was huge, both the bedroom and the living area. the flat panel tv's are big too. i dont think there was much "hallway traffic" but i never heard anyone walking by or any of my neighbours through the walls.had dinner at bull & bear with a girlfriend and everything was fantastic - the service, atmosphere (very busy for a weeknight at 10) drinks & wine and the meal itself! there were a lot of, er, questionable looking ladies there and it was certainly entertaining to see them in action loloverall this is a nice hotel - a manhattan classic - but it does need some updating. i will absolutely stay here again because of its location

Aug 13 2009 	Elegant and wonderful...old style NYC	After reading reviews on Trip Advisor I changed my reservation from the regular Waldorf Astoria room to the Towers. I am soooo glad I did. There is a special private check in desk for the Towers. I got a really great deal on Expedia and was very excited upon check in to find out I had been upgraded to an Executive Suite on a Concierge level. The room was huge (for NYC standards) with a beautiful marble foyer and seperate living room and bedroom. I had a large walk in closet + a coat closet in the foyer and a butlers kitchen with a full size refrigerator, sink, etc. There was a nice size flat screen TV in the living room and one in the bedroom. The room was very elegant and had a feel of "old style" New York. I have stayed at more modern hotels in NYC with beautiful accomodations however this felt more like NYC and definitely very elegant. The concierge level offers a special room that serves a light breakfast including cereals, breads, fruit, and boiled eggs. There was coffee, juice, and water available. There is no afternoon service as with most concierge hospitality rooms I have experienced and the room was always very crowded. One of my travel companions was turned away one morning and offered a voucher for the lobby breakfast on the main level. Although it was very crowded the staff made every attempt to keep things stocked and were always very helpful and polite even when the guests were not. We were asked everyday if our expectations were met as we left. One staff said to me "we want you to leave happy". Considering the crowd and how rude some of the guests were to the staff, I was impressed with their attitude. The staff were wonderful and the service was exactly what you would expect from the Waldorf. My only issue was that the floors were really slick and I fell in the foyer one evening. We called for ice and it took over 30 minutes for them to bring it up. (no self serve ice machines on the concierge level) Other than that this was a truly wonderful experience.

Aug 11 2009 	Tip: Book Concierge Level Room	Reviews of the Waldorf are mixed. Reviews of the much more expensive Waldorf Towers, on the other hand, are uniformly positive. Private elevators, 15-foot ceilings, twice daily maid service, and the standard rooms are easily suite-sized which is huge for NYC accommodations. Aug 11 2009	W=A is wow=awesome.	We travelled with a bus tour which we booked through Travac, an Ottawa travel agent located in the Westgate Shopping Plaza. We opted to start with a deep tissue massage at the Guerlain Spa on the 19th floor. This included a wonderful foot massage while we completed our questionnaire. We found all the W=A staff to be professional, sincere, respectful and very friendly. Our room, although small, was opulant, with marbled bathroom and a walk in closet big enough to dress in. There are far better out there at only a slightly higher price if you know where to look and the truth is this hotel knows it.Disappointing and in a time-warp.

Aug 5 2009 	Met my High Expectations	We stayed at the Waldorf to celebrate our anniversary. I am Hilton gold and we were staying on points. My daughter contacted an individual in management to request we receive special consideration. From the moment we arrived at the check in the service was incredible. We were upgraded to a suite and we received a complimentary gift to mark our occasion. We also enjoyed a fantastic dinner at the Bull and Bear at the hotel. As to some specifics, we were driving; the hotel car entrance off 50th St is a narrow alley that goes under and through the building. Initially the entrance was closed for security, as an ambassador was due to arrive, however his arrival was delayed which then allowed me to get in. The elevators are plentiful and fast. The room was wonderful, the hotel had a recent 'facelift', though close examination of the room revealed some character, the room was very charming. The bed was very comfortable and the showers were tremendous. In the parlor of the suite we could here some elevator mechanical sounds, however the bedroom was very peaceful. We were granted an extra hour for late check out. The hotel was very busy at check in, with a high rate of occupancy. Anticipating we were going to a nice place, we tried to dress for it, it seemed others were trying to make a different statement. To summarize- it is a grand hotel, if you allow it, it will take you back to a higher level of personal service. If you are trying to spend the least amount of money and see NYC it is not for you. People that retrieve cars, carry bags, and provide concierge reservations deserve tips, just like a server in a restaurant. I have stayed at the New York Hilton on Ave of the Americas and the Hilton Times Square, each have their place, but the Waldorf is that special place for something just a cut above.

Aug 5 2009 	A Palacial Hotel	Stayed at the Waldorf last year and it was truly a impeccable experience. Lobby was Grand and they have a old art piece of Clock right in the lobby. Room was spacious. Stairways, corridors, public areas were all Grand. They have a lot of boutique shops near the lobby. Infact in one of the boutiques, there was a set up made with fine pottery which was a mock up set up for a wedding set up done by the Waldorf... That was interesting. The lounge on the Ground Floor looked really grand with the Lavish use of Leather. Service was simply Great. If you walk around the hotel public areas, it is HUGE and sometimes you get lost if you are truly mesmerized with the Granduer. The history and grandeur of the Waldorf make it a wonderful and a memorable place to stay. It was indeed WORTH a STAY..

Aug 4 2009 	Wonderful and Historic Hotel	I stayed with family at this hotel for one night. There was a slight problem with our reservation that was resolved. We upgraded to a suite and our room was impressive for New York City. We had a full living room, bedroom with 2 beds, and 2 bathrooms. The decor in the room was not over the top, but was very nice nonetheless. The bathrooms featured marble tile and the showers were great!Apparently they do allow small pets for an additional fee. The person I was staying in my room with said that she detected a faint odor of pet urine in the living room, but I did could not smell it. Otherwise, the room seemed clean.I found the housekeeping service to be a bit informal and not what I would expect from a hotel like The Waldorf Astoria. We requested turn down service, and the housekeeper insisted that she begin working on the room before we were ready to leave for the evening (at about 7pm, even though I requested service to begin at 7:30pm). The housekeeper said that she was leaving that floor and didn't want to have to return at 7:30pm. I thought that was a bit odd, but I didn't object. When we returned later that evening, we found that she lowered the window shades, and replenished the towels - but didn't do much else (i.e., turn down beds, provide ice, chocolates, etc).The hotel is very elegant and the lobby, although busy, was wonderful. The lobby felt like a museum to me! If you happen to be there on a Sunday, the Sunday brunch (held in the lobby) is not to be missed!! It's very expensive, but well worth the price.I recommend this hotel to people who can appreciate a historic hotel that is showing its age gracefully. If you are looking for something modern, look elsewhere.

Aug 3 2009 	Magnificent	My wife and I stayed one night in the Waldorf for our wedding anniversary using our hilton honors points. It was like staying in an historic museum. The lobby was grand. It has old photos and artifacts of the hotel in glass showcases. The room is small, but it is old school and that is what I expected. The room was clean and nicely decorated. As a hilton honors gold member they gave us a choice of 2 free drinks at the bar, 100 Hilton points or starbuck coffee and danishes. We took the drinks. So after dinner we went back to the hotel and used our vouchers at the peacock alley bar. The drinks were good, but when I ordered a second drink (gray goose and cranberry) I was charged $18, wow.So to sum it up I highly recommend the hotel but drink elsewhere.

Jul 30 2009 	Trading on its name - avoid	Avoid the Waldorf Astoria. A stay there is like waking up beside a 1950's starlet...in 2009. Yes its name may conjour up glamour and elegance from years gone by but they don't seem to have spent a penny on this hotel since years gone by. The decor is shabby, the carpets are shabby, the room amenities are practically non existent and the service is decidely average. The doormen virtually ignore you as you enter the hotel or exit a cab...yet they'll still come running over at the last minute looking for their pound of flesh. Room service is particularly vile (and overpriced). I ordered something very light, it cost me $100 and I genuinely wouldn't give it to my dog. How can a hotel like this have ancient TV's and not flat screens?! This was my first (and last) stay at the Waldorf and I would advise anyone thinking of staying there to avoid it like the plague. There's little point in wasting your money, especially in these recessionary times. If you want to treat yourself in NYC, try the Plaza or even the Grand Hyatt which in my view is streets ahead of the Waldorf. Hilton need to give this place a massive facelift because at the moment it's living off its (diminishing) name.

Jul 29 2009 	Not what is was nor what it could be	The Waldorf has a great location, beautiful lobby and helpful staff. Unfortunately it is definitely showing it's age...not in a good way. Our room size was fine, but it looked a bit dingy- curtains have been hanging a long time and need cleaning, as did other things in the room. We had 3 people in our group and the room only had double beds which was difficult for us. We actually had a magnificent balcony, but it was unkept, with trash about, and not a stick of furniture on it! What a wasted amenity!!! On our departure I overheard someone saying he was moving to a different hotel since the Waldorf was, "ratty". I think he had a point.

Jul 25 2009 	A Wonderful Classic!	Stayed at the Waldorf with my wife for her birthday. A beautiful hotel in the heart of Manhattan. You can feel the history. I could imagine Marilyn Monroe walking down these hallways so many years ago. Hotel is perfectly located withing walking distance of 5th avenue shopping, Central Park, Rockefeller Center, Times Square etc. Is it the newest around? No. But it's a landmark in which Presidents have stayed! We loved it!

Jul 23 2009 	It was like staying in a Museum for a week!	I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at the Waldorf in March. We got a great deal off of Expedia, and we were not disappointed. It felt like we were living in a museum for the week. The history and grandeur of the Waldorf make it a wonderful place to stay. It has a central location, the rooms are clean and comfortable, and it is surrounded by some great places to eat/grab a snack. Due to it's age, it obviously is a bit dated, but this is part of its charm. If you're looking for flat screen tv's & a modern feel do not stay here - if you are looking to stay in a part of NY history - I would highly recommend it! We loved every minute of it!

Jul 23 2009 	From Montreal to NY at the Waldof Istoria	Well what can i say,it GREAT....BRING YOU RE CASH!!!everything here was super,but we will not pay 32 $ for two eggs and if you think of taking a apple from brunch buffet..36$ for buffet.Everything else was super,concierge gave us great info.Oh yes we did get great price on the room 216$ for one night.Good trip all

Jul 23 2009 	Worst Hotel Service	The quality of the Waldorfs customer service was the worst of any hotel I have ever stayed in. The check in line was long and our room was not available upon arrival, plus we had to wait well beyond the normal check in. To make it worse the staff could have cared less about our trouble This was really unexpected for a hotel of this class. As a frequent traveler I could not have been more disappointed. The rooms were comfortable and clean, restaurant food was good if they work on the service they may in fact actually get repeat business.

Jul 21 2009 	Elegant Hotel in Great Locatoin	My wife and I stayed three nights in the Waldorf Astoria in New York and were very happy with our stay. The entrance off Park Ave. and the lobby are very classy. The staff was friendly and our room was also very nice. We had a corner room that was clean and comfortable. A subway station is only a block away so you have easy access to the city through the subway or from the many cabs that line up in front of the hotel. The only complaint I have is the Bull and Bear Resturant located in the hotel. It is WAY to expensive for the quality of food and service provided. We only went to this resturant for it's convienience. I will write a separate review for the Bull and Bear. Overall, we were both very happy with our stay at the Waldorf and will consider staying there again.

Jul 20 2009 	Outstanding	Stayed at the Waldorf Astoria on honeymoon from 4th-8th July 2009 and had a fantastic time. The hotel is located on Park Avenue and is the perfect location away from the pandemonium of Times Square but in walking distance to eveything....5th Avenue, Grand Central Station, Rockefeller centre all about 5 minute walk. Central park and the Empire State building are about 10 minute walk but there is a line of taxis at the front door of the hotel. The Waldorf itself is spectacular. Anyone who says this hotel is tired must be used to staying in some fantastic places as my wife and I thought it was great. The front entrance is breath taking and our room was just as opulant with a lovely big marbel finished bathroom. We found the staff to be very friendly and received a complementary bottle of champagne on the first night to celebrate our honeymoon. We didnt eat or drink in the hotel so cant comment on that but there are loads of bars and restaurants nearby. We had a fantastic time there and would recommend it to anyone.

Jul 20 2009 	Geat location - great value	Got a great rate on the hilton website for our dates - yes the hotel is a little faded but this is part of the charm, I think. Lobby is great, rooms were large compared to other NY hotels. Lifts a little slow occasionally. Hard to beat the location and athmosphere.One little problem - we had three rooms - two were available on checkin, the third was to be ready in 30 minutes. After two hours of contacting the reception desk it was still not available. They were to call me when available but no call. When we eventually got the third room they told us it was available all along! With such a large hotel I guess the guests are just numbers. Also found the concierge (one guy, not all) with an aittitude.

Jul 19 2009 	Great Address Historic Hotel but just OK	Traveling 2 weeks in New England, We stayed in July for a couple of days with our teenage sons so they could experience a bit of NYC. I used Hilton points so I wasn't expecting the greatest rooms, no view, smaller etc. It was clean and visually nice, with the styling you'd expect but definately starting to show it's age. I'd guess that the last serious renovation of bathrooms was in the late 80s. The A/C wasn't great, it got cool enough but we could never seem to get the dampness totally out of the air. It's central air but I don't think the dials in the room actually control the temp other than the speed of the fan. This is our second stay here in 3 years and we were realistic about it so none of that really bothered us. We slept fine, although the bed was a little soft for my taste. My warning is that if you get the basic room here and are expecting a room with the grandeur of the Waldorf, you're going to be disapointed. Now the lobby, bars, resturants and the staff and all the rest is what you'd guess they would be.

Jul 15 2009 	Watch your credit card bill	I got a great deal through Continental, booking flight and hotel together for 2 adults and 2 teenagers. I compared pricing with the Plaza and found a suite at the Waldorf to be about half the price, having stayed here in June of 2008 and enjoying the experience, I decided to stay here again. We stayed on the Lexington side and noticed that it took a long amount of time to get elevators, unsure if several were out of order or what was wrong.Our room was nice, the decor was great but you could definitely see this is an old hotel but I guess that leads to some of it's charm, the art deco stylings. Each day of my stay I had to request additional towels, even though my reservation was for 4 people, I could only get 3 towels. I even told the clerk at check in "there are 4 people in this room." I checked out, was told they were not able to print me a bill. 3 weeks later, I found out why. I saw an odd charge on my credit card for $122.77. I called the hotel to ask what this charge was for, we had not taken any items from the room, ordered room service or billed anything to the room. The billing department advised me that Travelocity told them to bill me this fee for extra person charges. I called Travelocity (Apparently the company Continental Airlines uses) and they said they knew nothing of it, had no records of ever telling the hotel this. I was eventually told by travelocity that the receipt says my room was a double room rate, not a quad rate, even though it says the room is for 4 on my receipt. I ended up giving the issue to my credit card company saying I did not authorize the charges and eventually, I was refunded the money. I am not sure if Travelocity, Capital One, or the Waldorf are responisble for the refund because none of them bothered to call or email me with a resolution. Just like they didn't think it was worth it to tell me they were going to bill me extra....3 weeks after the stay. Apparently using 1 extra towel costs you an additional $122.77 at the Waldorf.

Jul 14 2009 	Excellent Experience	Over the last 20 years we've stayed at many hotels in NYC. Coming in from CT for Broadway weekends our thing is to stay at different hotels and try various restaurants in order to soak up the essence of NY. When we saw the special Waldorf rate it was time to experience the best. For $219 we upgraded to the deluxe king room. What a room!! High ceilings, fire place, 42" Flat Screen TV and a terrific view of the Chrysler Bldg. Our freinds weren't as lucky with the view but also had an awsome room. The Waldorf has one of the best lobbys you'll ever see. It's almost like going to a museum. At this rate one's lucky to get a basic room in a average hotel in NYC, take advantage while it lasts.

Jul 12 2009 	Loved this hotel	We stayed here for a week while visiting New York. We parked in the hotel and upon arrival our bags were removed and car was parked within minutes.Reception: Excellent service, fast efficient and very helpfulRoom: We had a corner room which was quite big by NY standards. It included a large walk-in wardrobe that accommodated all of our luggage. The room itself was a little old but was spotless and comfortable. Given what we have paid in similar priced hotels in NY this was easily the biggest room we have stayed in.Location: Perfectly located for all shops in 5th Avenue and approx a 15 minute walk to Union Square.Overall I would highly recommend this hotel. It is a little old fashioned, but the service was perfect and coupled with a fantastic room and location, it was well worth the cost.

Jul 9 2009 	BIGGEST DISAPPOINTMENT OF OUR LIVES	my wife and i booked this hotel for our honeymoon as we got married on 31/12/2008.prior to our arrival we made a point of informing the reservations desk that it was our honeymoon and we had hoped they would make an effort to make our stay memorable,they made it memorable,but for all the wrong reasons.1.very badly treated when paying for our stay in cash,as i had explained my credit card had a small limit as i dont use it often,verbally congratulated on our ocassion,thats it!2.requested a smoking room,none available on check in,no effort made to accomodate us,the best could be done was the following day,we were given our room the next day.3.the bath stopper was not working in our room,we ordered food in our room as we had just arrived from a long haul flight,we ordered burger and fries and were billed over 100 for our meal which was of a lesser quality than mc donalds,i disputed the bill on the grounds that we were not being treated fairly as it was our honeymoon.they deducted the meal from our account reluctantly following a lenghty call to the duty manager.4.reception failed to give us breakfast vouchers upon check in as we had the option of parking or breakfast and we opted for breakfast.we were told by the restaurant staff that we would be charged in full if we didnt present vouchers.we had to go back to reception and ask for our vouchers that we should have been presented with on check in.4.our final bill was almost $2,000 for the most heart sinking week of our lives.we had really looked forward to staying in thee most renowned hotel in the world.i will always remember the first night of our honeymoon as the night that i comforted and reassured my wife as she cried floods of tears and sobbed herself to sleep. This should have been the most memorable week of our lives,but sadly it was destroyed by the low standards of the best known hotel brand in the world.new york as a city was amazing and i would love to return.to give credit where it is due,the staff at this hotel were extremely warm and welcoming and i would not like to disrespect their professionalism as they are wonderful ambassadors for the company that they work for.this hotel is the equivalent of a 3 star hotel in ireland,we should be proud of our hospitality in ireland,this hotel could learn a few things from the irish hotel model.we were offered a 4 night complimentary stay in the waldorf towers from the general manager who was a very professional man in his approach,but you only get a first chance to make a lasting impression.

Jul 7 2009 	Think Twice Before Staying Here	Just stayed for a 4th of July 2009 visit to NY at the Waldorf. Have previously stayed at the Ritz, Palace, the Sherry Netherland and before renovation, the Plaza. Thought were getting a great deal for a single room - King for under $300 per night. Not so. We were on the Lexington side of the building (no view - but this was not my complaint). Here are the issues: stayed on 13th floor but visited other floors to confirm impression- once you've left the lobby and are on the Lexington tower you'll quickly notice some dramatic changes in quality and feel. Carpetting is very, very worn, does not look or smell clean or fresh. Gave me the same sense of cleanliness of the security checkpoint carpeting at the airport. Other than the ballroom floors, the hallways on the Lexington tower appeared to lack air conditioning and proper ventilation. I am 40 something guest....and never cared about ventilation before. Courtesy and personalized attention is non-existent (at least for patrons at this rate) - if you need anything more than to hand a tip or your credit card to anyone. The shower admittedly old, did not provide reasonable expectations of hot water or adequate pressure. The front desk attendees had a difficult time delivering a complete bill including mini bar charges. The mini bar had stale $6 potato chips. Room door is not well insulated. In the morning, we heard the whispers and non-whispers of a dutiful (and courteous) cleaning staff on the adjacent rooms. However, not a good sign if sleep is what you need. The TV appeared to be a $100 1990 Walmart purchase - my local Motel 6 has already updated to flat screens - not sure if too much to expect from the hotel touted as the only one where the President stays. Arrived very late at night with not another guest at the time. Nevetheless - it took over 35 minutes for the bags to make my room. It took me 3 minutes to get up to my room. We were pleased by the comfortable bedding. Not impressed by anything else. Hotel business center and computers are quite out of date. You share printers with others in a four computer small room. Difficult if you have sensitive business to work on. I thought this was unbelievable for a hotel of this magnitude. Person in charge of taking my bags for the afternoon after checkout would not stop asking what is my profession and whether business is good - not sure this is what I want to discuss with the hotel staff. Top notch, courteous, professional, personalized attention was non-existent. Does not favorably compare with any of the other five/four star staple hotels in NYC. I've never written a review before but thought this was an important one to write.
Jul 6 2009	Just good!	It was great, but also expensive...If money is not playing a big role for you, you should try it! Very beautiful grand hotel and one of the oldest!

Jul 6 2009 	Worth it-once(or twice) in a life time!	Outstanding from the great check in staff to the staff in the hallways. This hotel that was once owned by George Bolt of Bolt Castle fame on the St. Lawrence River(now mostly restored) lives up to it's previous reputation for greatness. The rooms bring you back to a time of pure elegance and fine service. From gold fixtures to wonderful bedding this is a must. The rates very widely so look deep into the travel websites for a bargain. You will need to save money somewhere to afford a cocktail at the Bull and Bear Bar-$17.50 per. we stayed here,but, now retired, ate off site. Cheap or frugal?

Jul 5 2009 	Wonderful honeymoon stay	What an amazing honeymoon, being in New York was fantastic staying at the Waldorf Astoria, Park Avenue was everything we expected from a 1930's iconic building as beautiful inside as outside. From the moment we walked into the foyer through the grand marbled corridor to the reception area we felt back in the era of Ginger Rogers, Lana Turner and Walter Pigeon. The service was wonderful, complementary chocolate strawberries and champagne and letters, we felt decadent and like film stars. The room was lovely on a corner on the 24th floor. The views were spectacular. The room was comfortable and big and the bed and bedding was so comfortable. We spent very happy evenings in the cocktail bar. It was the best honeymoon in the world and we loved it so much we're going back in August!

Jul 4 2009 	Dont compare it to other hotels...	Excellent old hotel with a "character", not comparable to the most other hotels in this price range: simply a "must have stayed"! Centrally located in midtown. Smooth check-in and -out. I stayed in the "Astoria level" (26th floor) in a clean and very spacious room; breakfast (on the same floor) was included in my price. Fantastic furniture in all rooms! WLAN was free - but only in the (very comfortable) lobby. I could not receive phone calls from outside directly (only via operator), which was not a problem in my case. Staff was friendly and efficient. On a business trip, I would recommend anyone to add one day extra just to enjoy this hotel, and New York, of course. But I would not refuse to stay for weeks, either...

Jun 29 2009 	Great history; Fun to have done it once	We were excited to stay at the historical Waldorf Astoria, to look at the pictures and marvel at the beautiful decor in the lobby - and it was very interesting to see and read about the history... but the charm ended there. No one was rude, but I expected better service and more attention and have gotten better service from many other hotels. I'm happy we stayed there, but next time I think we'll shoot for staying somewhere in Times Square closer to the action for the same price. For first-time tourists, I recommend walking to Times Square - it's a straight shot down 49th and only about 10 blocks and you pass Rockefeller Plaza, Radio City Music Hall and 5th Avenue all on the way. Go there for dinner and drinks and save yourself some money!

Jun 29 2009 	fabulous hotel	after searching for the "perfect" hotel getaway, I choosed the waldorf. I read all previous reviews and went with an open mind. I couldnt have selected a more beautiful, well appointed hotel, it still has all the glamour and history I was expecting. Our room was upgraded to a suite, the appointments were gorgeous, the bed fabulous, linens perfect, this room had it all. I was very pleased with the selection. The front checking was wonderful, easy, fast, the desk staff was friendly, smiling, happy to be working at such a classic hotel. When asking for anything every staff member was friendly and willing to go the extra, I had a wonderful stay at such a fabulous hotel, I would go again, without a doubt.

Jun 27 2009 	Nice but not what I expected!	We arrived around 6pm by limo. The hotel staff in the parking area were to say the least uninterested in our arrival and I had to find one of them to take care of our luggage. We were given what was described as an upgraded room, that was a little disappointing. It could do with some TLC and redecorating. The staff were great, all being helpful and couteous.A couple of weeks before this stay, we stayed at the Hilton New York and have to say our suite there was more comfortable and our welcome to the hotel more professional. We were really made to feel welcome there. Not as nice as we had expected!

Jun 24 2009 	Having stayed in luxury hotels worldwide the Waldorf falls way short of expectation.	Initial impressions of the Waldorf were poor and nothing happened for us to change our minds.Queueing in a long line on arrival for reception was annoying and the receptionist just rattled off what was an obvious sales pitch when she asked us if we'd like to eat. We were in a "king superior" which was spacious and clean, but backed on to 49th Avenue where garbage vans work constantly from 5-10.30pm every weekday emptying out the rubbish from the office block opposite. Forget trying to sleep while this is going on, even if you have jetlag travelling from the UK. Breakfast in the Peacock restaurant was $33 for the worst buffet I've ever seen or eaten. Actually "buffet" is an exaggeration, there were just a few slices of processed cheese, 2 (!!) slices of inedible meat, some bread and fresh fruit (the melon was disgusting) to choose from. The waiter had the nerve to tell us we couldn't share like we were schoolchildren. Breakfast downstairs serves up a decent fruit bowl with a choice of bread - a mere $28. On the last day of our stay, we went down the road to the deli and had the same breakfast for $10 each.You have to queue for the concierge as well as reception, this time to be told they didn't have any brollies to lend us. Knowing traders were waiting outside and selling them for $5.This is a hotel still relying on past glories. The large reception hall is bling Art Deco, as are the ladies restrooms, but behind this grandeur, there's a tired feel to the place. The Waldorf is part of the Hilton group who continue to rely on its previous high reputation and status, charge ludicrous amounts of money for everything and expect people to put up with it. Well, wrong, we'll stay elsewhere next time we're in New York.

Jun 23 2009 	Much better this time	I already wrote a review of this hotel last year, and am writing for a second time, as my recent staty there was much better; actually very good. I do not whether it is a diffferent room or service is getting better during the downturn. The quality of the room was great, all systems worked fine, and staff was courteous.

Jun 22 2009 	Jackpot!	Although I was concerned after reading some reviews I kept our reservations at the WA in NY for the beginning of our vacation. I'm SO GLAD I did! I rec'd excellent service from the first reservation call, the 2 calls prior to arriving (I was nervous because some member pics of the beds made them look small), to the day we checked out. Nothing short of "bend over backwards for us!" We got what I think is the "expedia" room because the view I've seen in pics too. It is not the Park Ave view, but I can't expect that for the expedia price I paid, but it was a good view of the Chrysler Bldg. and the room was actually quite large with a walk in closet. Edgar the doorman was a hoot! He recommended Pizza at Angelo's and it was perfect. Not a far walk either. We also walked to Ess-a-bagel and didn't get yelled at--even though we hoped we would just to get that NY feel! haha! They were delicious. Everyone that we encountered at the hotel were great, except the waiters in the lobby bar where we stopped for a welcome cocktail with the free beverage coupon they gave us. But we had kids and they probably didn't want to be bothered with them. Our room was stale smelling upon arrival but what can you expect form an older hotel. I asked for freshener and Mason was there in less than 10 minutes to spray an orange scented freshener and it was fine. My rating from 1-10--WA gets a 9!We wanted "kid friendly" apps and drinks one night so we stopped by TGI Fridays. HORRIBLE mistake! Horrible horrible service, the food tasted like it had been sitting around for days. Save your money and take the ecommendations of hotel staff instead.

Jun 18 2009 	Awesome building service Sucks	I went to stay at this hotel for 2 days to celebrate a mini-honeymoon. The check in process was nice, and the guy at the front desk told me that he was sending me a complimentary strawberry and champagne package.That's where the excellent service ended. Two days and three phone calls later, there were no strawberries and there was no champagne. I also made a reservation at the steakhouse, bulls and bears, through the hotel phone (from my room). When I reached the restaurant, the maitr'd told me that he had no record of my reservation. He did not apologize for it; instead he seemed to try to make me feel sorry for visiting the restaraunt without a reservation. Despite several empty seats, he sat my fiancee and I in a cramped space surrounded by other people. We left the place and went to a much friendlier and nicer steakhouse.The Waldorf Astoria hotel has excellent history, but needs to get its act together. I will never stay there again

Jun 17 2009 	Shabby but you have to go	Let's be upfront - I was thrilled to be booked into the Waldorf Astoria, even though anticipating that it would be a faded and worn shadow of its Thirties glory. And it was, but I would still go again with the family just to share with them a New York landmark.Stayed in three rooms over 4 nights. The first room was tiny with two double beds lacking any form of back support. Was moved to a quirky mini-suite overlooking the front entrance. This is the sort of room which makes staying in an old hotel so memorable. It had an entrance foyer, bedroom, a huge dressing room (large enough for a small couch, dressing table and two armoires) and an art deco bathroom on a raised platform. Incredible. The third room was a nicer version of the first.All the rooms were worn and in need of repainting, new furniture and carpets. But it was all well worth staying for the fireplaces in the halls, lobby area and the ability to say that you stayed at the Waldorf=Astoria.

Jun 13 2009 	Absolutely fantastic!	Stayed here 6th - 8th June as part of a 5-night NY trip to celebrate a 50th birthday. From the moment we arrived till the moment we left we were treated so well, the staff were all pleasant, helpful, attentive, no pretentiousness, and a real credit to the hospitality industry! We were upgraded to a suite which was absolutely beautifully furnished and spotlessly clean. The bathroom had plentiful towels and toiletries, the shower had power, the bed was huge and the living area with its gorgeous chandelier was just magnificent! The staff sent up a bottle of bubbly to help us celebrate too! We had a couple of drinks in Sir Harry's bar where the high standard of service was replicated, nice dish of complimentary mixed nuts! - and the prices weren't too bad in comparsion to the big measures!Wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel, you just cannot fault it.

Jun 7 2009 	The good and bad of an old school hotel	New York city is unique to the world, and I like staying in uniquely New York hotels when I'm there. The Waldorf definitely qualifies. It has the great lobby, half a dozen food/drink options, and the feel of something old and wise. The lobby is always hopping, which I love. That said, the hotel doesn't do anything super - the rooms are small, some areas are a little worn, they don't always have enough people working the front desk, etc. But, for me, this is so much better than the cookie-cutter hotel experience that you will get at the big chains, even in NYC. When you wake up and stumble into the lobby, you won't forget what city you're in, and that's worth something. The Waldorf gets a thumbs up.

The only downside to this decision is that the bar set by the Waldorf=Astoria can never be reached by anywhere else and my kids will now measure every other hotel by this stay. Jun 2 2009 	An Old Grand Place...	We just came back from a three-night stay with our two kids. The Waldorf is very different from our "usual," which tends to be more of the boutique, home-style, 4 or 5-star places. The Waldorf is old style. Grand. Old glamour. Traditional. It has some really great features, such as thick walls, heavy real wood doors and furniture, thick gold-colored drapes, real heavy handles for the bathroom door (so it's much easier to open when you have just put lotion on your hands!), door bell and mail slot, etc. The one and only downside is there is no free wi-fi (amazing in this day and age; even at the Hampton Inn there is free wi-fi!). The hotel is enormous and obviously caters to a convention/group crowd. The public areas are very nice and they showcase the long history of the hotel. Definitely NOT a boutique hotel experience. May 21 2009 	Beautiful Hotel rooms vary	My sister and I were visiting NY and booked the Waldorf 7 months in advance. We arrived at 1 am without luggage as the airline had lost our luggage. Great staff at both the front desk and restaurant.

May 14 2009 	Wonderful Stay; Can't Wait to Return	Having read mixed reviews of the Waldorf on Tripadvisor, I was a little worried about having booked it. Fortunately, I had the most fantastic stay, and ended up being impressed in just about every regard. The hotel is itself one of the most beautiful in New York; the entrance lobby with its stunning mosaic floor and grandly old-world crystal chandelier was always such a happy place to come home to, and the main lobby is itself a feast of beautiful woodwork and lavish craftmanship. Indeed, despite being an old hotel, the main floor has been renovated and maintained to perfection. The rooms themselves are older, it's true--yet ours had clearly been recently redone, as everything was immaculate, from the lovely new carpet and drapes to the marble-topped bedside table and desk. My one complaint was that the tub in the bathroom had obviously not been redone in years; however, the bathroom was nevertheless dripping in marble, and as nice as everything else was, I quickly got over that one quibble. And of course, everything was utterly spotless, as clean and well-maintained as could be.Having said that, make no mistake--the Waldorf *is* an old-fashioned hotel, and if you crave everything being modern then you will probably not care for the decor or the overall presentation. However, it is all incontrovertibly classy, and truly a wonderful place to stay. The location is absolutely perfect, too, central while still being peaceful and refined. I was there for a week, and it quickly came to feel like home; I was more sorry to leave it than I have been to leave any hotel in quite some time, and I am already looking forward to returning the next time I am in New York.Just the same, there are compromises, as with any hotel. Parts of the hotel outside the main floor *are* old, and while in my opinion that adds to the Waldorf's charm, it will not be to the taste of everyone. Taken as a whole, the hotel is probably not as well maintained as a Ritz-Carlton, for instance, would be. However, a room at the Waldorf can be had for vastly less than a comparable room at the Ritz or the Plaza, and frankly, for all that we got for the very good price we paid, I can't see that it would be hugely worth spending the extra money to stay elsewhere. The service we received was beyond reproach, from the concierge who got us last minute dinner reservations at a top New York restaurant to the staff who came to our room and would not accept a tip for their labors. I was disappointed initially, as our room was too dark for my taste; however, when we called, they quickly brought us an extra floor lamp that righted the problem immediately. (A word to the wise--if anything bothers you, simply ask; the staff is extremely kind, and at least in my experience, did everything possible to keep us happy.) Also, I should note that the lobby is often crowded with people and tourists (the Waldorf gives tours), which can be an aggravation; nevertheless, the hotel itself is incredibly quiet, and that never bothered me too much. On the plus side, there was a buzziness to it such that the bars were really fun, and while the drinks were expensive, I loved being able to go down in the evening and take advantage of the free ground-floor wireless internet while sipping a marvelous cocktail and enjoying the nightly piano music. In closing, despite its shortcomings, I absolutely loved the Waldorf, and in spite of what some of the reviews on here would leave you to believe, I would recommend it without reservation.
